<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Mexico</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>

<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in North America</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Mexico_(disambiguation)" title="Mexico (disambiguation)">Mexico (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p>
<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1073938472">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Mexico&amp;params=23_N_102_W_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">23°N</span> <span class="longitude">102°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">23°N 102°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">23; -102</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>

<li value="1"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1041539562">.mw-parser-output .citation{word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}</style><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_iboxa"><b><a href="#ref_iboxa">^</a></b></span> Article 4 of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Law_of_Linguistic_Rights_of_the_Indigenous_Peoples" title="General Law of Linguistic Rights of the Indigenous Peoples">General Law of Linguistic Rights of the Indigenous Peoples</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup></li><li value="2"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_iboxb"><b><a href="#ref_iboxb">^</a></b></span> Spanish is <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> the official language in the Mexican federal government.</li>
</ol></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Mexico</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[a]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[b]</a></sup> officially the <b>United Mexican States</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[c]</a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states" title="List of sovereign states">country</a> in the southern portion of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>. It is <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Mexico" title="Borders of Mexico">bordered</a> to the north by the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>; to the south and west by the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>; to the southeast by <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belize" title="Belize">Belize</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a>; and to the east by the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[11]</a></sup> Mexico covers 1,972,550 square kilometers (761,610 sq mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia.gov_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-15">[12]</a></sup> making it the world's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_area" title="List of countries by area">13th-largest country</a> by area; with approximately 126,014,024 inhabitants,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-2"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup> it is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">10th-most-populous</a> country and has the <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone#Hispanosphere" title="Hispanophone">most Spanish-speakers</a>. Mexico is organized as a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federal</a> republic comprising 31 <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_of_Mexico" title="List of states of Mexico">states</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>, its capital. Other <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Mexico" title="Metropolitan areas of Mexico">major urban areas</a> include <a href="/wiki/Monterrey" title="Monterrey">Monterrey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puebla_(city)" title="Puebla (city)">Puebla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toluca" title="Toluca">Toluca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tijuana" title="Tijuana">Tijuana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Ciudad Juárez">Ciudad Juárez</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n,_Guanajuato" title="León, Guanajuato">León</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_Mexico" title="Pre-Columbian Mexico">Pre-Columbian Mexico</a> traces its origins to 8,000 <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">BCE</a> and is identified as one of the world's six <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization" title="Cradle of civilization">cradles of civilization</a>. In particular, the <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerican region</a> was home to many intertwined civilizations; including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olmec" title="Olmec">Olmec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_civilization" title="Zapotec civilization">Zapotec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">Teotihuacan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pur%C3%A9pecha_Empire" title="Purépecha Empire">Purepecha</a>. Last were the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aztec" title="Aztec">Aztecs</a>, who dominated the region in the century before <a href="/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="European colonization of the Americas">European contact</a>. In 1521, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> and its indigenous allies <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Aztec_Empire" title="Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire">conquered the Aztec Empire</a> from its capital <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Tenochtitlan</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>), establishing the colony of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_New_Spain" title="Kingdom of New Spain">New Spain</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[14]</a></sup>  Over the next three centuries, Spain and the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Mexico" title="Catholic Church in Mexico">Catholic Church</a> played an important role expanding the territory, enforcing Christianity and spreading the Spanish language throughout.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[15]</a></sup> With the discovery of rich deposits of silver in <a href="/wiki/Zacatecas_City" title="Zacatecas City">Zacatecas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guanajuato_City" title="Guanajuato City">Guanajuato</a>, New Spain soon became one of the most important mining centers worldwide. Wealth <a href="/wiki/Manila_galleon" title="Manila galleon">coming from Asia</a> and the New World contributed to Spain's status as a major world power for the next centuries, and brought about a <a href="/wiki/Price_revolution" title="Price revolution">price revolution</a> in Western Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[16]</a></sup> The colonial order came to an end in the early nineteenth century with the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">War of Independence</a> against Spain.
</p><p>Mexico's early history as an independent <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> was marked by political and socioeconomic upheaval, both domestically and in foreign affairs. The <a href="/wiki/Federal_Republic_of_Central_America" title="Federal Republic of Central America">Federal Republic of Central America</a> shortly seceded the country. Then two invasions by foreign powers took place: first, by the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> as a consequence of the <a href="/wiki/Texas_Revolution" title="Texas Revolution">Texas Revolt</a> by <a href="/wiki/Manifest_destiny" title="Manifest destiny">American settlers</a>, which led to the <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican–American War">Mexican–American War</a> and huge <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Mexico" title="Territorial evolution of Mexico">territorial losses</a> in 1848.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[17]</a></sup> After the introduction of liberal <a href="/wiki/La_Reforma" title="La Reforma">reforms</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_1857" title="Constitution of 1857">Constitution of 1857</a>, conservatives reacted with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_of_the_Reform" title="War of the Reform">war of Reform</a> and prompted France to <a href="/wiki/Second_French_intervention_in_Mexico" title="Second French intervention in Mexico">invade the country</a> and install an <a href="/wiki/Second_Mexican_Empire" title="Second Mexican Empire">Empire</a>, against the Republican resistance led by liberal President <a href="/wiki/Benito_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Benito Juárez">Benito Juárez</a>, which emerged victorious. The last decades of the 19th century were dominated by the dictatorship of <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">Porfirio Díaz</a>, who sought to modernize Mexico and restore order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[18]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Porfiriato" title="Porfiriato">Porfiriato</a> era led to great social unrest and ended with the outbreak in 1910 of the decade-long <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a> (civil war). This conflict had profound changes in Mexican society, including the proclamation of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">1917 Constitution</a>, which remains in effect to this day. The remaining war generals ruled as a succession of presidents until the <a href="/wiki/Institutional_Revolutionary_Party" title="Institutional Revolutionary Party">Institutional Revolutionary Party</a> (PRI) emerged in 1929. The PRI in turn governed Mexico for the next 70 years, first under a set of paternalistic developmental policies of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_miracle" title="Mexican miracle">considerable economic success</a>. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> Mexico also played an important role for the U.S. war effort.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[20]</a></sup> Nonetheless, the PRI regime resorted to <a href="/wiki/Tlatelolco_massacre" title="Tlatelolco massacre">repression</a> and <a href="/wiki/1988_Mexican_general_election" title="1988 Mexican general election">electoral fraud</a> to maintain power; and moved the country to a more US-aligned <a href="/wiki/Neoliberalism" title="Neoliberalism">neoliberal</a> economic policy during the late 20th century. This culminated with the signing of the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">North American Free Trade Agreement</a> in 1994, which caused a major <a href="/wiki/Zapatista_Army_of_National_Liberation" title="Zapatista Army of National Liberation">indigenous rebellion</a> in the state of <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>. PRI lost the presidency for the first time in <a href="/wiki/2000_Mexican_general_election" title="2000 Mexican general election">2000</a>, against the conservative party (<a href="/wiki/National_Action_Party_(Mexico)" title="National Action Party (Mexico)">PAN</a>).
</p><p>Mexico is a <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a>, ranking 74th on the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, but has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">15th-largest economy by nominal GDP</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th-largest by PPP</a>, with the United States being its largest economic partner. Its large economy and population, cultural influence, and steady democratization make Mexico a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[24]</a></sup> it is often identified as an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emerging_Powers" title="Emerging Powers">emerging power</a> but is considered a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized state</a> by several analysts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Globalization2_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-Globalization2-29">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Limits2_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-Limits2-30">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AIA2_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-AIA2-31">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Principles2_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-Principles2-32">[29]</a></sup> Mexico ranks <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Mexico" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Mexico">first in the Americas and seventh in the world</a> for the number of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[30]</a></sup> It is also one of the world's 17 <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>, ranking fifth in natural <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[31]</a></sup> Mexico's rich cultural and biological heritage, as well as varied climate and geography, makes it a major tourist destination: as of 2018, it was the sixth most-visited country in the world, with 39 million international arrivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[32]</a></sup> However, the country continues to struggle with social inequality, <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Mexico" title="Poverty in Mexico">poverty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Mexico" title="Crime in Mexico">extensive crime</a>. It ranks poorly on the <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[33]</a></sup> due in large part to ongoing conflict between <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Drug_trafficking" title="Drug trafficking">drug trafficking</a> syndicates, which violently compete for the US drug market and trade routes. This "<a href="/wiki/Mexican_drug_war" title="Mexican drug war">drug war</a>" has led to over 120,000 deaths since 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cfrdeaths_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-cfrdeaths-37">[34]</a></sup> Mexico is a member of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD), the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> forum, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Latin_American_and_Caribbean_States" title="Community of Latin American and Caribbean States">Community of Latin American and Caribbean States</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico">Name of Mexico</a></div>
<p><span title="Nahuatl languages collective text"><i lang="nah"><a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico">Mēxihco</a></i></span> is the <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a> term for the heartland of the <a href="/wiki/Aztec_Empire" title="Aztec Empire">Aztec Empire</a>, namely the <a href="/wiki/Valley_of_Mexico" title="Valley of Mexico">Valley of Mexico</a> and surrounding territories, with its people being known as the <a href="/wiki/Mexica" title="Mexica">Mexica</a>. The terms are plainly linked; it is generally believed that the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toponym" title="Toponym">toponym</a> for the valley was the origin of the primary <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a> for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aztec_Triple_Alliance" title="Aztec Triple Alliance">Aztec Triple Alliance</a>, but it may have been the other way around.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bright2004_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bright2004-38">[35]</a></sup> In the colonial era (1521–1821) Mexico was called <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a>. In the eighteenth century, this central region became the <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Intendency of Mexico</a>, during the reorganization of the empire, the <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_Reforms" title="Bourbon Reforms">Bourbon Reforms</a>. After New Spain achieved independence from the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> in 1821 and became a sovereign state, the territory came to be known as the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">State of Mexico</a>, with the new country being named after its capital: <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>, which itself was founded in 1524 on the site of the ancient Mexica capital of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexico-Tenochtitlan" title="Mexico-Tenochtitlan">Mexico-Tenochtitlan</a>. The official name of the country has changed as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Form_of_government" title="Form of government">form of government</a> has changed. The declaration of independence signed on 6 November 1813 by the deputies of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congress_of_An%C3%A1huac" title="Congress of Anáhuac">Congress of Anáhuac</a> called the territory <i><a href="/wiki/Solemn_Act_of_the_Declaration_of_Independence_of_Northern_America" title="Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America">América Septentrional</a></i> (Northern America); the 1821 <a href="/wiki/Plan_of_Iguala" title="Plan of Iguala">Plan of Iguala</a> also used América Septentrional. On two occasions (1821–1823 and 1863–1867), the country was known as <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Imperio Mexicano</i></span> (<a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Mexican_Empire_(disambiguation)" title="Mexican Empire (disambiguation)">Mexican Empire</a>). All three federal constitutions (1824, 1857 and 1917, the current constitution) used the name <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Estados Unidos Mexicanos</i></span><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[36]</a></sup>—or the variant <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Estados-Unidos Mexicanos</i></span>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[37]</a></sup> all of which have been translated as "United Mexican States". The phrase <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">República Mexicana</i></span>, "Mexican Republic", was used in the 1836 <a href="/wiki/Siete_Leyes" title="Siete Leyes">Constitutional Laws</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico" title="History of Mexico">History of Mexico</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Catholic_Church_in_Mexico" title="History of the Catholic Church in Mexico">History of the Catholic Church in Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico" title="Economic history of Mexico">Economic history of Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_democracy_in_Mexico" title="History of democracy in Mexico">History of democracy in Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico_City" title="History of Mexico City">History of Mexico City</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Mexico" title="Military history of Mexico">Military history of Mexico</a></div>
<h3><span id="Indigenous_civilizations_before_European_contact_.28pre-1519.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_civilizations_before_European_contact_(pre-1519)">Indigenous civilizations before European contact (pre-1519)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_Mexico" title="Pre-Columbian Mexico">Pre-Columbian Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_chronology" title="Mesoamerican chronology">Mesoamerican chronology</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5963r.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2362" data-file-width="3543" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5963r.JPG/220px-Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5963r.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5963r.JPG/330px-Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5963r.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5963r.JPG/440px-Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5963r.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5963r.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>View of the <a href="/wiki/Pyramid_of_the_Sun" title="Pyramid of the Sun">Pyramid of the Sun</a> in the ancient city-state of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">Teotihuacan</a>, which was the 6th largest city in the world at its peak (1 AD to 500 AD)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chichen_Itza_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5197" data-file-width="9771" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Chichen_Itza_3.jpg/220px-Chichen_Itza_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Chichen_Itza_3.jpg/330px-Chichen_Itza_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Chichen_Itza_3.jpg/440px-Chichen_Itza_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chichen_Itza_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/El_Castillo,_Chichen_Itza" title="El Castillo, Chichen Itza">Temple of Kukulcán (El Castillo)</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Maya_city" title="Maya city">maya city</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chichen_Itza" title="Chichen Itza">Chichen Itza</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/220px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/330px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/440px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mural by Diego Rivera depicting a view from the <a href="/wiki/Tlatelolco_(altepetl)" title="Tlatelolco (altepetl)">Tlatelolco</a> markets into <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Mexico-Tenochtitlan</a>, the largest city in the Americas at the time.</div></div></div>
<p>The prehistory of Mexico stretches back millennia. The earliest <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">human</a> artifacts in Mexico are chips of <a href="/wiki/Stone_tool" title="Stone tool">stone tools</a> found near campfire remains in the Valley of Mexico and radiocarbon-dated to circa 10,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001386–_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001386–-42">[39]</a></sup> Mexico is the site of the domestication of maize, tomato, and <a href="/wiki/Phaseolus" title="Phaseolus">beans</a>, which produced an agricultural surplus. This enabled the transition from <a href="/wiki/Paleo-Indians" title="Paleo-Indians">paleo-Indian</a> hunter-gatherers to sedentary agricultural villages beginning around 5000 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EvansWebster2013_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-EvansWebster2013-43">[40]</a></sup>
In the subsequent formative eras, maize cultivation and cultural traits such as a mythological and religious complex, and a <a href="/wiki/Vigesimal" title="Vigesimal">vigesimal</a> (base 20) numeric system, were diffused from the Mexican cultures to the rest of the <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerican</a> culture area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MacLachlan_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-MacLachlan-44">[41]</a></sup> In this period, villages became more dense in terms of population, becoming socially stratified with an artisan class, and developing into <a href="/wiki/Chiefdom" title="Chiefdom">chiefdoms</a>. The most powerful rulers had religious and political power, organizing the construction of large ceremonial centers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest complex civilization in Mexico was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olmec" title="Olmec">Olmec</a> culture, which flourished on the Gulf Coast from around 1500 BCE. Olmec cultural traits diffused through Mexico into other formative-era cultures in Chiapas, Oaxaca and the Valley of Mexico. The formative period saw the spread of distinct religious and symbolic traditions, as well as artistic and architectural complexes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[43]</a></sup> The formative-era of Mesoamerica is considered one of the six independent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cradles_of_civilization" title="Cradles of civilization">cradles of civilization</a>. In the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_chronology" title="Mesoamerican chronology">pre-classical period</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_civilization" title="Zapotec civilization">Zapotec</a> civilizations developed complex centers at <a href="/wiki/Calakmul" title="Calakmul">Calakmul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Monte_Alb%C3%A1n" title="Monte Albán">Monte Albán</a>, respectively. During this period the first true <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_writing_systems" title="Mesoamerican writing systems">Mesoamerican writing systems</a> were developed in the <a href="/wiki/Epi-Olmec_culture" title="Epi-Olmec culture">Epi-Olmec</a> and the Zapotec cultures. The Mesoamerican writing tradition reached its height in the Classic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maya_Script" title="Maya Script">Maya Hieroglyphic script</a>. The earliest written histories date from this era. The tradition of writing was important after the Spanish conquest in 1521, with indigenous scribes learning to write their languages in alphabetic letters, while also continuing to create pictorial texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Central Mexico, the height of the classic period saw the ascendancy of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">Teotihuacán</a>, which formed a military and commercial empire whose political influence stretched south into the Maya area as well as north. Teotihuacan, with a population of more than 150,000 people, had some of the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_pyramid" title="Mesoamerican pyramid">pyramidal structures</a> in the pre-Columbian Americas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[46]</a></sup> After the collapse of Teotihuacán around 600 AD, competition ensued between several important political centers in central Mexico such as <a href="/wiki/Xochicalco" title="Xochicalco">Xochicalco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cholula_(Mesoamerican_site)" title="Cholula (Mesoamerican site)">Cholula</a>. At this time, during the Epi-Classic, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nahua_people" title="Nahua people">Nahua peoples</a> began moving south into Mesoamerica from the North, and became politically and culturally dominant in central Mexico, as they displaced speakers of <a href="/wiki/Oto-Manguean_languages" title="Oto-Manguean languages">Oto-Manguean languages</a>. During the early post-classic era (ca. 1000–1519 CE), Central Mexico was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Toltec" title="Toltec">Toltec</a> culture, <a href="/wiki/Oaxaca" title="Oaxaca">Oaxaca</a> by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mixtec_civilization" title="Mixtec civilization">Mixtec</a>, and the lowland Maya area had important centers at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chich%C3%A9n_Itz%C3%A1" title="Chichén Itzá">Chichén Itzá</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mayap%C3%A1n" title="Mayapán">Mayapán</a>. Toward the end of the post-Classic period, the Mexica established dominance, establishing a political and economic empire based in the city of Tenochtitlan (modern Mexico City), extending from central Mexico to the border with Guatemala.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[47]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">Alexander von Humboldt</a> popularized the modern usage of "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aztec" title="Aztec">Aztec</a>" as a collective term applied to all the people linked by trade, custom, religion, and language to the <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Mexica state</a> and Ēxcān Tlahtōlōyān, the <a href="/wiki/Aztec_Empire" title="Aztec Empire">Triple Alliance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[48]</a></sup> In 1843, with the publication of the work of William H. Prescott, it was adopted by most of the world, including 19th-century Mexican scholars who considered it a way to distinguish present-day Mexicans from pre-conquest Mexicans. This usage has been the subject of debate since the late 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Port_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-Port-52">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Aztec empire was an informal or hegemonic empire because it did not exert supreme authority over the conquered territories; it was satisfied with the payment of tributes from them. It was a discontinuous empire because not all dominated territories were connected; for example, the southern peripheral zones of <a href="/wiki/Soconusco" title="Soconusco">Xoconochco</a> were not in direct contact with the center. The hegemonic nature of the Aztec empire was demonstrated by their restoration of local rulers to their former position after their city-state was conquered. The Aztec did not interfere in local affairs, as long as the tributes were paid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[50]</a></sup> The Aztec of Central Mexico built a tributary empire covering most of central Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Human_sacrifice_in_Aztec_culture" title="Human sacrifice in Aztec culture">The Aztec were noted for practicing human sacrifice</a> on a large scale. Along with this practice, they avoided killing enemies on the battlefield. Their warring casualty rate was far lower than that of their Spanish counterparts, whose principal objective was immediate slaughter during battle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[52]</a></sup> This distinct Mesoamerican cultural tradition of human sacrifice ended with the gradually Spanish conquest in the 16th century. Other Mexican indigenous cultures were conquered and gradually subjected to Spanish colonial rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the colonial era and through to the twenty-first century, the indigenous roots of Mexican history and culture are essential to Mexican identity. The <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Anthropology_(Mexico)" title="National Museum of Anthropology (Mexico)">National Museum of Anthrology</a> in Mexico City is the showcase of the nation's prehispanic glories. Historian <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enrique_Florescano" title="es:Enrique Florescano">Enrique Florescano</a> calls it "a national treasure and a symbol of identity. The museum is the synthesis of an ideological, scientific, and political feat."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[54]</a></sup> Mexican Nobel laureate <a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a> said of the museum that the "exaltation and glorification of Mexico-Tenochtitlan transforms the Museum of Anthropology into a temple."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[55]</a></sup> Mexico pursued international recognition of its prehispanic heritage, and has a large number of <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_by_country" title="World Heritage Sites by country">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>, the largest in the hemisphere. The existence of high indigenous civilization prior to the arrival of Europeans has also had an impact on European thought.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Spanish_conquest_and_colonial_era_.281519.E2.80.931821.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_conquest_and_colonial_era_(1519–1821)">Spanish conquest and colonial era (1519–1821)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_Mexico" title="Spanish conquest of Mexico">Spanish conquest of Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Leutze,_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="921" data-file-width="1050" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg/220px-Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg/330px-Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg/440px-Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Leutze,_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Storming of the <a href="/wiki/Teocalli" title="Teocalli">Teocalli</a> by <a href="/wiki/Hern%C3%A1n_Cort%C3%A9s" title="Hernán Cortés">Cortez</a> and his Troops</i> (1848)</div></div></div>
<p>Although the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> had established colonies in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> starting in 1493, only in the second decade of the sixteenth century did they begin exploring the east coast of Mexico. The Spanish first learned of Mexico during the <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Grijalva" title="Juan de Grijalva">Juan de Grijalva</a> expedition of 1518. The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Aztec_Empire" title="Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire">Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire</a> began in February 1519 when <a href="/wiki/Hern%C3%A1n_Cort%C3%A9s" title="Hernán Cortés">Hernán Cortés</a> landed on the Gulf Coast and founded the Spanish city of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Veracruz,_Veracruz" title="Veracruz, Veracruz">Veracruz</a>. Around 500 <a href="/wiki/Conquistador" title="Conquistador">conquistadores</a>, along with horses, cannons, swords, and long guns gave the Spanish some technological advantages over indigenous warriors, but key to the Spanish victory was making strategic alliances with disgruntled indigenous city-states (<i><a href="/wiki/Altepetl" title="Altepetl">altepetl</a></i>) who fought with them against the Aztec Triple Alliance. Also important to the Spanish victory was Cortés's cultural translator, Malinche, a Nahua woman enslaved in the Maya area whom the Spanish acquired as a gift. She quickly learned Spanish and gave strategic advice about how to deal with both indigenous allies and indigenous foes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Spanish conquest is well documented from multiple points of view. There are accounts by the Spanish leader Cortés<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[58]</a></sup> and multiple other Spanish participants, including <a href="/wiki/Bernal_D%C3%ADaz_del_Castillo" title="Bernal Díaz del Castillo">Bernal Díaz del Castillo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[60]</a></sup> There are indigenous accounts in Spanish, Nahuatl, and pictorial narratives by allies of the Spanish, most prominently the Tlaxcalans, as well as <a href="/wiki/Tetzcoco_(altepetl)" title="Tetzcoco (altepetl)">Texcocans</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[61]</a></sup> and Huejotzincans, and the defeated Mexica themselves, recorded in the last volume of <a href="/wiki/Bernardino_de_Sahag%C3%BAn" title="Bernardino de Sahagún">Bernardino de Sahagún</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Florentine_Codex" title="Florentine Codex">General History of the Things of New Spain</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vista_de_la_Plaza_Mayor_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Cristobal_de_Villalpando.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1963" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vista_de_la_Plaza_Mayor_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Cristobal_de_Villalpando.jpg/220px-Vista_de_la_Plaza_Mayor_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Cristobal_de_Villalpando.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vista_de_la_Plaza_Mayor_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Cristobal_de_Villalpando.jpg/330px-Vista_de_la_Plaza_Mayor_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Cristobal_de_Villalpando.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vista_de_la_Plaza_Mayor_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Cristobal_de_Villalpando.jpg/440px-Vista_de_la_Plaza_Mayor_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Cristobal_de_Villalpando.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vista_de_la_Plaza_Mayor_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Cristobal_de_Villalpando.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>View of the Plaza Mayor (today <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%B3calo" title="Zócalo">Zócalo</a>) in Mexico City (ca. 1695) by <a href="/wiki/Crist%C3%B3bal_de_Villalpando" title="Cristóbal de Villalpando">Cristóbal de Villalpando</a></div></div></div>
<p>The 1521 <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Capture_of_Tenochtitlan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Capture of Tenochtitlan (page does not exist)">capture of Tenochtitlan</a> and immediate founding of the Spanish capital <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a> on its ruins was the beginning of a 300-year-long colonial era during which Mexico was known as <i>Nueva España</i> (<a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a>). Two factors made Mexico a jewel in the Spanish Empire: the existence of large, hierarchically-organized Mesoamerican populations that rendered tribute and performed obligatory labor and the discovery of vast silver deposits in northern Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[65]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_New_Spain" title="Kingdom of New Spain">Kingdom of New Spain</a> was created from the remnants of the Aztec empire. The two pillars of Spanish rule were the State and the Roman Catholic Church, both under the authority of the Spanish crown. In 1493 the pope had granted <a href="/wiki/Patronato_real" title="Patronato real">sweeping powers</a> to the Spanish monarchy for its overseas empire, with the proviso that the crown spread Christianity in its new realms. In 1524, <a href="/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor">King Charles I</a> created the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Indies" title="Council of the Indies">Council of the Indies</a> based in Spain to oversee State power its overseas territories; in New Spain the crown established a high court in Mexico City, the <i><a href="/wiki/Real_Audiencia" title="Real Audiencia">Real Audiencia</a>,</i> and then in 1535 created the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain" title="Viceroyalty of New Spain">Viceroyalty of New Spain</a>. The viceroy was highest official of the State. In the religious sphere, the diocese of Mexico was created in 1530 and elevated to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archdiocese_of_Mexico" title="Archdiocese of Mexico">Archdiocese of Mexico</a> in 1546, with the archbishop as the head of the ecclesiastical hierarchy, overseeing Roman Catholic clergy. Castilian Spanish was the language of rulers. The Catholic faith the only one permitted, with non-Catholics (Jews and Protestants) and Catholics (excluding Indians) holding unorthodox views being subject to the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Inquisition" title="Mexican Inquisition">Mexican Inquisition</a>, established in 1571.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the first half-century of Spanish rule, a network of Spanish cities was created, sometimes on pre-Columbian sites where there were dense indigenous populations. The capital Mexico City was and remains the premier city, but other cities founded in the sixteenth century remain important, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puebla_de_los_Angeles" title="Puebla de los Angeles">Puebla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guanajuato" title="Guanajuato">Guanajuato</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zacatecas" title="Zacatecas">Zacatecas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oaxaca_City" title="Oaxaca City">Oaxaca</a>, and the port of <a href="/wiki/Veracruz" title="Veracruz">Veracruz</a>. Cities and towns were hubs of civil officials, ecclesiastics, business, Spanish elites, and mixed-race and indigenous artisans and workers. When deposits of silver were discovered in sparsely populated northern Mexico, far from the dense populations of central Mexico, the Spanish secured the region against fiercely resistant indigenous <a href="/wiki/Chichimeca_War" title="Chichimeca War">Chichimecas</a>. The Viceroyalty at its greatest extent included the territories of modern Mexico, <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">Central America</a> as far south as Costa Rica, and the western United States. The Viceregal capital Mexico City also administrated the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_West_Indies" title="Spanish West Indies">Spanish West Indies</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a> (that is, the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Florida" title="Spanish Florida">Spanish Florida</a>. In 1819, the Spain signed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adams-On%C3%ADs_Treaty" title="Adams-Onís Treaty">Adams-Onís Treaty</a> with the United States, setting New Spain's northern boundary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1586" data-file-width="3121" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Map_of_the_Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain.svg/290px-Map_of_the_Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Map_of_the_Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain.svg/435px-Map_of_the_Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Map_of_the_Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain.svg/580px-Map_of_the_Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a> was essential to the Spanish global trading system. White represents the route of the Spanish <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manila_Galleon" title="Manila Galleon">Manila Galleons</a> in the Pacific and the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_treasure_fleet" title="Spanish treasure fleet">Spanish convoys</a> in the Atlantic. (Blue represents <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India_Armadas" title="Portuguese India Armadas">Portuguese routes.)</a></div></div></div>
<p>The rich deposits of silver, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Zacatecas" title="Zacatecas">Zacatecas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guanajuato" title="Guanajuato">Guanajuato</a>, resulted in silver extraction dominating the economy of New Spain. Mexican silver pesos became the first globally used currency. <a href="/wiki/Royal_fifth" title="Royal fifth">Taxes on silver production</a> became a major source of income for the Spanish monarchy. Other important industries were the agricultural and ranching  <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haciendas" title="Haciendas">haciendas</a> and mercantile activities in the main cities and ports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[68]</a></sup>  As a result of its trade links with Asia, the rest of the Americas, Africa and Europe and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_silver_trade_from_the_16th_to_18th_centuries" title="Global silver trade from the 16th to 18th centuries">profound effect of New World silver</a>, central Mexico was one of the first regions to be incorporated into a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Globalized" title="Globalized">globalized</a> economy. Being at the crossroads of trade, people and cultures, Mexico City has been called the "first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_city" title="World city">world city</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[69]</a></sup> The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nao_de_China" title="Nao de China">Nao de China</a></i> (Manila Galleons) operated for two and a half centuries and connected New Spain with Asia. Silver and the red dye <a href="/wiki/Cochineal" title="Cochineal">cochineal</a> were shipped from Veracruz to Atlantic ports in the Americas and Spain. Veracruz was also the main port of entry in mainland New Spain for European goods, immigrants from Spain, and African slaves. The <i><a href="/wiki/Camino_Real_de_Tierra_Adentro" title="Camino Real de Tierra Adentro">Camino Real de Tierra Adentro</a></i> connected Mexico City with the interior of New Spain.
</p><p>The population of Mexico was overwhelmingly indigenous and rural during the entire colonial period and beyond, despite the massive decrease in their numbers due to epidemic diseases. Diseases such as smallpox, measles, and others were introduced by Europeans and African slaves, especially in the sixteenth century. The indigenous population stabilized around one to one and a half million individuals in the 17th century from the most commonly accepted five to thirty million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Population_history_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas">pre-contact population</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCaa_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-McCaa-73">[70]</a></sup> During the three hundred years of the colonial era, Mexico received between 400,000 and 500,000 Europeans,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[71]</a></sup> between 200,000 and 250,000 African slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[72]</a></sup> and between 40,000 and 120,000 Asians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under Viceroy <a href="/wiki/Juan_Vicente_de_G%C3%BCemes,_2nd_Count_of_Revillagigedo" title="Juan Vicente de Güemes, 2nd Count of Revillagigedo">Revillagigedo</a> the first comprehensive census was created in 1793, with racial classifications. Although most of its original datasets have reportedly been lost, thus most of what is known about it comes from essays and field investigations made by scholars who had access to the census data and used it as reference for their works such as German scientist <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">Alexander von Humboldt</a>. Europeans ranged from 18% to 22% of New Spain's population, Mestizos from 21% to 25%, Indians from 51% to 61% and Africans were between 6,000 and 10,000. The total population ranged from 3,799,561 to 6,122,354. It is concluded that the population growth trends of whites and mestizos were even, while the percentage of the indigenous population decreased at a rate of 13%–17% per century, mostly due to the latter having higher mortality rates from living in remote locations and being in constant war with the colonists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aleph_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-aleph-78">[75]</a></sup> Independence-era Mexico eliminated the legal basis for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Castas" title="Castas">hierarchical system of racial classification</a>, although the racial/ethnic labels continued to be used.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6586" data-file-width="5404" decoding="async" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg/170px-Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg/255px-Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg/340px-Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Luis_de_Mena" title="Luis de Mena">Luis de Mena</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Virgin_of_Guadalupe" title="Virgin of Guadalupe">Virgin of Guadalupe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Casta" title="Casta">castas</a>, showing race mixture and hierarchy as well as fruits of the realm,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[76]</a></sup> ca. 1750</div></div></div>
<p>Colonial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Law_in_Spain" title="Law in Spain">law with Spanish roots</a> was introduced and attached to native customs creating a hierarchy between local jurisdiction (the <a href="/wiki/Cabildo_(council)" title="Cabildo (council)">Cabildos</a>) and the Spanish Crown. Upper administrative offices were closed to native-born people, even those of pure Spanish blood (<a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">criollos</a>). Administration was based on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Racial_separation" title="Racial separation">racial separation</a>. Society was organized in a racial hierarchy, with whites on top, mixed-race persons and blacks in the middle, and indigenous at the bottom. There were formal legal designations of racial categories. The Republic of Spaniards (<i>República de Españoles</i>) comprised European- and American-born Spaniards, mixed-race <a href="/wiki/Casta" title="Casta">castas</a>, and black Africans. The Republic of Indians (<i>República de Indios</i>) comprised the indigenous populations, which the Spanish lumped under the term Indian (<i>indio</i>), a Spanish colonial social construct which indigenous groups and individuals rejected as a category. Spaniards were exempt from paying tribute, Spanish men had access to higher education, could hold civil and ecclesiastical offices, were subject to the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Inquisition" title="Mexican Inquisition">Inquisition</a>, and liable for military service when the standing military was established in the late eighteenth century. Indigenous paid tribute, but were exempt from the Inquisition, indigenous men were excluded from the priesthood; and exempt from military service. Although the racial system appears fixed and rigid, there was some fluidity within it, and racial domination of whites was not complete.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cope,_R._Douglas_1994_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cope,_R._Douglas_1994-80">[77]</a></sup> Since the indigenous population of New Spain was so large, there was less labor demand for expensive black slaves than other parts of Spanish America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[79]</a></sup> In the late eighteenth century the crown instituted <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_Reforms" title="Bourbon Reforms">reforms</a> that privileged Iberian-born Spaniards (<i>peninsulares</i>) over American-born (<i>criollos</i>), limiting their access to offices. This discrimination between the two became a sparking point of discontent for white elites in the colony.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Marian_apparition" title="Marian apparition">Marian apparition</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Virgin_of_Guadalupe" title="Virgin of Guadalupe">Virgin of Guadalupe</a> said to have appeared to the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Juan_Diego" title="Juan Diego">Juan Diego</a> in 1531 gave impetus to the evangelization of central Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-huff_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-huff-85">[82]</a></sup> The Virgin of Guadalupe became a symbol for American-born Spaniards' (<i>criollos</i>) patriotism, seeking in her a Mexican source of pride, distinct from Spain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[83]</a></sup> The Virgin of Guadalupe was invoked by the insurgents for independence who followed Father <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo" title="Miguel Hidalgo">Miguel Hidalgo</a> during the War of Independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-huff_85-1"><a href="#cite_note-huff-85">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>Spanish military forces, sometimes accompanied by native allies, led expeditions to conquer territory or quell rebellions through the colonial era. Notable Amerindian revolts in sporadically populated northern New Spain include the <a href="/wiki/Chichimeca_War" title="Chichimeca War">Chichimeca War</a> (1576–1606),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[84]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tepehu%C3%A1n_Revolt" title="Tepehuán Revolt">Tepehuán Revolt</a> (1616–1620),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[85]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Pueblo_Revolt" title="Pueblo Revolt">Pueblo Revolt</a> (1680), the <a href="/wiki/Tzeltal_Rebellion_of_1712" title="Tzeltal Rebellion of 1712">Tzeltal Rebellion of 1712</a> was a regional Maya revolt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[86]</a></sup> Most rebellions were small-scale and local, posing no major threat to the ruling elites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[87]</a></sup> To protect Mexico from the attacks of English, French, and Dutch <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pirates" title="Pirates">pirates</a> and protect the Crown's monopoly of revenue, only two ports were open to foreign trade—Veracruz on the Atlantic and Acapulco on the Pacific. Among the best-known pirate attacks are the 1663 <a href="/wiki/Sack_of_Campeche_(1663)" title="Sack of Campeche (1663)">Sack of Campeche</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[88]</a></sup> and 1683 <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Veracruz" title="Attack on Veracruz">Attack on Veracruz</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[89]</a></sup> Of greater concern to the crown was of foreign invasion, especially after Britain seized in 1762 the Spanish ports of Havana, Cuba and Manila, the Philippines in the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>. It created a standing military, increased coastal fortifications, and expanded the northern <a href="/wiki/Presidio" title="Presidio">presidios</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_missions_in_California" title="Spanish missions in California">missions</a> into <a href="/wiki/Alta_California" title="Alta California">Alta California</a>. The volatility of the urban poor in Mexico City was evident in the 1692 riot in the Zócalo. The riot over the price of maize escalated to a full-scale attack on the seats of power, with the viceregal palace and the archbishop's residence attacked by the mob.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cope,_R._Douglas_1994_80-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cope,_R._Douglas_1994-80">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Independence_era_.281808.E2.80.931821.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_era_(1808–1821)">Independence era (1808–1821)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Batalla_de_la_Alh%C3%B3ndiga_de_Granaditas.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="454" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Batalla_de_la_Alh%C3%B3ndiga_de_Granaditas.jpg/220px-Batalla_de_la_Alh%C3%B3ndiga_de_Granaditas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Batalla_de_la_Alh%C3%B3ndiga_de_Granaditas.jpg/330px-Batalla_de_la_Alh%C3%B3ndiga_de_Granaditas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Batalla_de_la_Alh%C3%B3ndiga_de_Granaditas.jpg/440px-Batalla_de_la_Alh%C3%B3ndiga_de_Granaditas.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Batalla_de_la_Alh%C3%B3ndiga_de_Granaditas.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Siege of the Alhondiga de Granaditas, Guanajuato, 28 Sept. 1810.</div></div></div>
<p>The upheaval in the Spanish Empire that resulted in the independence of most of its New World territories was due to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Napoleon_Bonaparte" title="Napoleon Bonaparte">Napoleon Bonaparte</a>'s invasion of Spain in 1808. Napoleon forced the abdication of the Spanish monarch <a href="/wiki/Charles_IV_of_Spain" title="Charles IV of Spain">Charles IV</a> and imposed of his brother <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Bonaparte" title="Joseph Bonaparte">Joseph Bonaparte</a> as the Spanish king. Now with an alien usurper on the Spanish throne, there was a crisis of legitimacy of the monarchy, resulting in various responses in both Spain and Spanish America. In Mexico, elites argued that sovereignty now reverted to "the people" and that town councils (<i><a href="/wiki/Cabildo_(council)" title="Cabildo (council)">cabildos</a></i>) were the most representative bodies.  American-born Spaniards petitioned the viceroy <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_Iturrigaray" title="José de Iturrigaray">José de Iturrigaray</a> (1803–08) to convene a junta to determine rule in Mexico in the current political crisis. Although Peninsular-born Spaniards were opposed to the plan, the viceroy called together wealthy landowners, miners, merchants, ecclesiastics, academics, and members of cabildos. They failed to come to agreement, and in the meantime, Peninsular-born Spaniards took the initiative, arresting Iturrigaray and leading creole elites in the capital. The coup ended what could have been a peaceful process toward political autonomy in Mexico.  Creoles now sought extralegal means to achieve their political aspirations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 16 September 1810, secular priest <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo_y_Costilla" title="Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla">Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla</a> declared against "bad government" in the small town of <a href="/wiki/Dolores_Hidalgo" title="Dolores Hidalgo">Dolores</a>, Guanajuato. This event, known as the <a href="/wiki/Cry_of_Dolores" title="Cry of Dolores">Cry of Dolores</a> (Spanish: <i>Grito de Dolores</i>) is commemorated each year, on 16 September, as Mexico's independence day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[91]</a></sup> The first insurgent group was formed by Hidalgo, army captain <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_Allende" title="Ignacio Allende">Ignacio Allende</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Militia" title="Militia">militia</a> captain <a href="/wiki/Juan_Aldama" title="Juan Aldama">Juan Aldama</a> and the wife of the local magistrate (<i>Corregidor</i>) <a href="/wiki/Josefa_Ortiz_de_Dom%C3%ADnguez" title="Josefa Ortiz de Domínguez">Josefa Ortiz de Domínguez</a>, known as <i>La Corregidora</i>. Hidalgo's local declaration sparked a huge revolt of the masses, an uncontrollable uprising targeting the persons and property of white elites, whether Peninsular- or American-born. Famously in Guanajuato, elites took refuge in the central grain storage <i>(alhondiga)</i>, bringing their treasure, attempted to hold out against Hidalgo's followers, but were slaughtered. In an event emblematic of the war of independence, "Hidalgo's capture of the great silver city of Guanajuato on September 28, 1810, is the most famous single episode of the decade-long insurgency."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[92]</a></sup> Hidalgo and some of his soldiers were eventually captured, Hidalgo was defrocked, and they were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Executed_by_firing_squad" title="Executed by firing squad">executed by firing squad</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chihuahua,_Chihuahua" title="Chihuahua, Chihuahua">Chihuahua</a>, on 31 July 1811. The heads of the executed rebels were subsequently displayed on the granary. Following Hidalgo's death, <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_L%C3%B3pez_Ray%C3%B3n" title="Ignacio López Rayón">Ignacio López Rayón</a> and then by the priest <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Morelos" title="José María Morelos">José María Morelos</a> assumed the leadership, occupying key southern cities with the support of <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Matamoros" title="Mariano Matamoros">Mariano Matamoros</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Bravo" title="Nicolás Bravo">Nicolás Bravo</a>. In 1813 the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Chilpancingo" title="Congress of Chilpancingo">Congress of Chilpancingo</a> was convened and, on 6 November, signed the "<a href="/wiki/Solemn_Act_of_the_Declaration_of_Independence_of_Northern_America" title="Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America">Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America</a>". This Act also called for the abolition of slavery and the system of racial hierarchy, and Roman Catholicism the sole religion. Morelos was captured and executed on 22 December 1815.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_Three_Guarantees.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1400" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_the_Three_Guarantees.svg/220px-Flag_of_the_Three_Guarantees.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_the_Three_Guarantees.svg/330px-Flag_of_the_Three_Guarantees.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_the_Three_Guarantees.svg/440px-Flag_of_the_Three_Guarantees.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_Three_Guarantees.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Flag of the <a href="/wiki/Army_of_the_Three_Guarantees" title="Army of the Three Guarantees">Army of the Three Guarantees</a>, the force formed by ex-royalist Iturbide and insurgent <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a> in February 1821</div></div></div>
<p>In subsequent years, the insurgency was a stalemate, but in 1820 when Spanish liberals seized power in Spain, and Mexican conservatives worried about the imposition of liberal principles overseas, including curtailment of the power of the Catholic Church.  Royalist <a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">criollo</a> general <a href="/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_de_Iturbide" title="Agustín de Iturbide">Agustín de Iturbide</a> was to continue fighting against <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a> and insurgents in the south. Instead of attacking Guerrero, Itubide approached Guerrero to join forces to seize power in Mexico. Iturbide issued the <a href="/wiki/Plan_of_Iguala" title="Plan of Iguala">Plan of Iguala</a> on 24 February 1821. Sometimes called the Act of Independence, it called for  Roman Catholicism as the nation's sole religion; the establishment of a constitutional monarchy; and the equality of those born in Spain and those born in Mexico, the "three guarantees" can be summarized as "religion, independence, and union". All were to be equal citizens in the new sovereign nation, regardless of place of birth or racial category, a requirement that Guerrero, the mixed-race leader of the insurgency, insisted on for his joining with Iturbide. The flag of the newly formed <a href="/wiki/Army_of_the_Three_Guarantees" title="Army of the Three Guarantees">Army of the Three Guarantees</a> has evolved into today's Mexican flag.  On 24 August 1821 in incoming Viceroy and Iturbide signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Treaty of Córdoba">Treaty of Córdoba</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Independence_of_the_Mexican_Empire" title="Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire">Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire</a>", which recognized the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Independence_of_Mexico" title="Independence of Mexico">independence of Mexico</a> under the terms of the Plan of Iguala. The Spanish crown repudiated the 1821 treaty and did not formally recognize the independence of Mexico until 1836.
</p>
<h3><span id="Early_Post-Independence_.281821.E2.80.931855.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Post-Independence_(1821–1855)">Early Post-Independence (1821–1855)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Empire" title="First Mexican Empire">First Mexican Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Republic" title="First Mexican Republic">First Mexican Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Centralist_Republic_of_Mexico" title="Centralist Republic of Mexico">Centralist Republic of Mexico</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican-American_War" title="Mexican-American War">Mexican-American War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_Mexican_Empire_(orthographic_projection).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="541" data-file-width="541" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/First_Mexican_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/220px-First_Mexican_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/First_Mexican_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/330px-First_Mexican_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/First_Mexican_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/440px-First_Mexican_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_Mexican_Empire_(orthographic_projection).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of the <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Empire" title="First Mexican Empire">First Mexican Empire</a></div></div></div>
<p>The first 35 years after Mexico's independence were marked by political instability and the changing of the Mexican state from a transient monarchy to a fragile federated republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[93]</a></sup> There were military coups d'état, foreign invasions, ideological conflict between Conservatives and Liberals, and <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico" title="Economic history of Mexico">economic stagnation</a>. Catholicism remained the only permitted religious faith and the Catholic Church as an institution retained its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fueros" title="Fueros">special privileges</a>, prestige, and property, a bulwark of Conservatism. The army, another Conservative-dominated institution, also retained its privileges. Former Royal Army General Agustín de Iturbide, became regent, as newly independent Mexico sought a <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Empire" title="First Mexican Empire">constitutional monarch</a> from Europe. When no member of a European royal house desired the position, Iturbide himself was declared Emperor Agustín I. The young and weak United States was the first country to recognize Mexico's independence, sending an ambassador to the court of the emperor and sending a message to Europe via the <a href="/wiki/Monroe_Doctrine" title="Monroe Doctrine">Monroe Doctrine</a> not to intervene in Mexico. The emperor's rule was short (1822–23) and he was overthrown by army officers in the <a href="/wiki/Plan_of_Casa_Mata" title="Plan of Casa Mata">Plan of Casa Mata</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the forced abdication of the monarch, the <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Republic" title="First Mexican Republic">First Mexican Republic</a> was established. In 1824, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_1824" title="Constitution of 1824">constitution of a federated republic</a> was promulgated and former insurgent General <a href="/wiki/Guadalupe_Victoria" title="Guadalupe Victoria">Guadalupe Victoria</a> became the first president of the republic, the first of many army generals to holding the presidency of Mexico. Central America, including Chiapas, left the union. In 1829, former insurgent general and fierce Liberal <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a>, a signatory of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plan_de_Iguala" title="Plan de Iguala">Plan de Iguala</a> that achieved independence, became president in a disputed election. During his short term in office, April to December 1829, he abolished slavery. As a visibly mixed-race man of modest origins, Guerrero was seen by white political elites as an interloper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[95]</a></sup> His Conservative vice president, former Royalist General <a href="/wiki/Anastasio_Bustamante" title="Anastasio Bustamante">Anastasio Bustamante</a>, led a coup against him and Guerrero was judicially murdered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[96]</a></sup> There was constant strife between Liberals, supporters of a <a href="/wiki/Federal_republic" title="Federal republic">federal form of decentralized government</a> and often called Federalists and their political rivals, the Conservatives, who proposed a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">hierarchical form of government</a>, were termed Centralists.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna,_siglo_XIX,_%C3%B3leo_sobre_tela.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2527" decoding="async" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna%2C_siglo_XIX%2C_%C3%B3leo_sobre_tela.png/170px-Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna%2C_siglo_XIX%2C_%C3%B3leo_sobre_tela.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna%2C_siglo_XIX%2C_%C3%B3leo_sobre_tela.png/255px-Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna%2C_siglo_XIX%2C_%C3%B3leo_sobre_tela.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna%2C_siglo_XIX%2C_%C3%B3leo_sobre_tela.png/340px-Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna%2C_siglo_XIX%2C_%C3%B3leo_sobre_tela.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna,_siglo_XIX,_%C3%B3leo_sobre_tela.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>General <a href="/wiki/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna" title="Antonio López de Santa Anna">Antonio López de Santa Anna</a></div></div></div>
<p>Mexico's ability to maintain its independence and establish a viable government was in question. Spain attempted to <a href="/wiki/Spanish_attempts_to_reconquer_Mexico" title="Spanish attempts to reconquer Mexico">reconquer</a> its former colony during the 1820s, but eventually recognized its independence. France attempted to recoup losses it claimed for its citizens during Mexico's unrest and blockaded the Gulf Coast during the so-called <a href="/wiki/Pastry_War" title="Pastry War">Pastry War</a> of 1838–39.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[97]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna" title="Antonio López de Santa Anna">Antonio López de Santa Anna</a> lost a leg in combat during this conflict, which he used for political purposes to show his sacrifice for the nation. Emerging as a national hero in defending Mexico was creole army general, fought the Spanish invasion, Santa Anna came to dominate the politics for the next 25 years, often known as the "Age of Santa Anna", until his own overthrow in 1855.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[98]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico also contended with indigenous groups which controlled territory that Mexico claimed in the north.
