PRD emerged after what has now been proven was a stolen election in 1988,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[169]</a></sup> and has won numerous state and local elections since then. PAN won its first governorship in 1989, and won the presidency in 2000 and 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[170]</a></sup> A new political party, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Regeneration_Movement" title="National Regeneration Movement">National Regeneration Movement</a> (MORENA), a leftist-populist party, emerged after the 2012 election and dominated the <a href="/wiki/2018_Mexican_general_election" title="2018 Mexican general election">2018 Mexican general election</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[171]</a></sup>  Unlike many <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin American</a> countries, the military in Mexico does not participate in politics and is under civilian control,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[172]</a></sup> the result of the concerted effort of revolutionary generals who became presidents of Mexico (1920–40) to remove the military from politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Mexico transitioned from one-party rule in 2000, increasingly criminal cartels have attempted to meddle in politics and have an impact on electoral outcomes.  Cartels have moved from bribing or otherwise influencing politicians and now attempt to have their preferred candidates elected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[174]</a></sup> A recent publication based on two decades of analysis of data contends that "electoral competition and partisan conflict were key drivers of the outbreak of Mexico's crime wars, the intensification of violence, and the expansion of war and violence to the spheres of local politics and civil society."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Mexico" title="Foreign relations of Mexico">Foreign relations of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Edificio_Tlatelolco_(S.R.E).JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG/220px-Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG/330px-Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG/440px-Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Edificio_Tlatelolco_(S.R.E).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Mexico)" title="Secretariat of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)">Secretariat of Foreign Affairs</a></div></div></div>
<p>The foreign relations of Mexico are directed by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Mexico" title="President of Mexico">President of Mexico</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPEUM89_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-CPEUM89-179">[176]</a></sup> and managed through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Mexico)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SRE_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-SRE-180">[177]</a></sup> The principles of the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy" title="Foreign policy">foreign policy</a> are constitutionally recognized in the Article 89, Section 10, which include: respect for <a href="/wiki/International_law" title="International law">international law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">legal equality of states</a>, their <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Independence" title="Independence">independence</a>, trend to <a href="/wiki/Non-interventionism" title="Non-interventionism">non-interventionism</a> in the domestic affairs of other countries, <a href="/wiki/Dispute_resolution" title="Dispute resolution">peaceful resolution of conflicts</a>, and promotion of <a href="/wiki/International_security" title="International security">collective security</a> through active participation in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_organizations" title="International organizations">international organizations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPEUM89_179-1"><a href="#cite_note-CPEUM89-179">[176]</a></sup> Since the 1930s, the <a href="/wiki/Estrada_Doctrine" title="Estrada Doctrine">Estrada Doctrine</a> has served as a crucial complement to these principles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-estradadoctrine_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-estradadoctrine-181">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico is founding member of several international organizations, most notably the United Nations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[179]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Velázquez_Flores_2007,_p._145_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-Velázquez_Flores_2007,_p._145-183">[180]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[181]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/OPANAL" title="OPANAL">OPANAL</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[182]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Latin_American_and_Caribbean_States" title="Community of Latin American and Caribbean States">CELAC</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[183]</a></sup> In 2008, Mexico contributed over 40 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_dollar" title="American dollar">dollars</a> to the United Nations regular budget.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unbudget_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-unbudget-187">[184]</a></sup> In addition, it was the only Latin American member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> since it joined in 1994 until <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> gained full membership in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico is considered a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-regionalpower_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-regionalpower-190">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-regionalpower2_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-regionalpower2-191">[188]</a></sup> hence its presence in major economic groups such as the <a href="/wiki/G8%2B5" title="G8+5">G8+5</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G-20</a>. In addition, since the 1990s Mexico has sought a <a href="/wiki/Reform_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Reform of the United Nations Security Council">reform of the United Nations Security Council and its working methods</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foreign_Affairs_2005_p._215_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-Foreign_Affairs_2005_p._215-192">[189]</a></sup> with the support of Canada, Italy, Pakistan and other nine countries, which form a group informally called the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coffee_Club" title="Coffee Club">Coffee Club</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coffeeclub_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-coffeeclub-193">[190]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Armed_Forces" title="Mexican Armed Forces">Mexican Armed Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Mexico" title="Military history of Mexico">Military history of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2100" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="238" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/170px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/255px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/340px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Navy" title="Mexican Navy">Mexican Navy</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurocopter" title="Eurocopter">Eurocopter</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Mexican military "provides a unique example of a military leadership's transforming itself into a civilian political elite, simultaneously transferring the basis of power from the army to a civilian state."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[191]</a></sup> The transformation was brought about by revolutionary generals in the 1920s and 1930s, following the demise of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Army" title="Federal Army">Federal Army</a> following its complete defeat during the decade-long Mexican Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[192]</a></sup> The Mexican Armed Forces are administered by the Secretariat of National Defense (<i>Secretaria de Defensa Nacional</i>, SEDENA). There are two branches: the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Army" title="Mexican Army">Mexican Army</a> (which includes the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Air_Force" title="Mexican Air Force">Mexican Air Force</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Navy" title="Mexican Navy">Mexican Navy</a>. The Secretariat of Public Security and Civil Protection has jurisdiction over the National Guard, which was formed in 2019 from the disbanded Federal Police and military police of the Army and Navy. Figures vary on personnel, but as of are approximately 223,000 armed forces personnel (160,000 Army; 8,000 Air Force; 55,000 Navy, including about 20,000 marines); approximately 100,000 National Guard (2021). Government expenditures on the military are a small proportion of GDP 0.7% of GDP (2021 est.), 0.6% of GDP (2020).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Mexican Armed Forces maintain significant infrastructure, including facilities for design, research, and testing of weapons, vehicles, aircraft, naval vessels, defense systems and electronics; military industry manufacturing centers for building such systems, and advanced naval dockyards that build heavy military vessels and advanced missile technologies. Since the 1990s, when the military escalated its role in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" title="Mexican Drug War">war on drugs</a>, increasing importance has been placed on acquiring airborne surveillance platforms, aircraft, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Helicopters" title="Helicopters">helicopters</a>, digital war-fighting technologies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-197">[194]</a></sup> urban warfare equipment and rapid troop transport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[195]</a></sup> Mexico has the capabilities to manufacture nuclear weapons, but abandoned this possibility with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tlatelolco" title="Treaty of Tlatelolco">Treaty of Tlatelolco</a> in 1968 and pledged to only use its nuclear technology for peaceful purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[196]</a></sup>  Mexico signed the UN treaty on the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, Mexico has remained neutral in international conflicts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[198]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexico_in_World_War_II" title="Mexico in World War II">with the exception of World War II</a>. However, in recent years some political parties have proposed an amendment of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">Constitution</a> to allow the Mexican Army, Air Force or Navy to collaborate with the United Nations in <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping missions</a>, or to provide military help to countries that officially ask for it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-neutral_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-neutral-202">[199]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_crime">Law enforcement and crime</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Mexico" title="Law enforcement in Mexico">Law enforcement in Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Mexico" title="Crime in Mexico">Crime in Mexico</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" title="Mexican Drug War">Mexican Drug War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking_in_Mexico" title="Human trafficking in Mexico">Human trafficking in Mexico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Femicide_in_Mexico" title="Femicide in Mexico">femicide in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:D%C3%ADa_del_Polic%C3%ADa_Federal.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3441" data-file-width="4884" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/D%C3%ADa_del_Polic%C3%ADa_Federal.jpg/220px-D%C3%ADa_del_Polic%C3%ADa_Federal.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/D%C3%ADa_del_Polic%C3%ADa_Federal.jpg/330px-D%C3%ADa_del_Polic%C3%ADa_Federal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/D%C3%ADa_del_Polic%C3%ADa_Federal.jpg/440px-D%C3%ADa_del_Polic%C3%ADa_Federal.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:D%C3%ADa_del_Polic%C3%ADa_Federal.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_Federal_Police" title="Mexican Federal Police">Mexican Federal Police</a> celebration.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1520" data-file-width="2288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/220px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/330px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/440px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Demonstration on 26 September 2015, in the first anniversary of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2014_Iguala_mass_kidnapping" title="2014 Iguala mass kidnapping">disappearance of the 43 students</a> in the Mexican town of <a href="/wiki/Iguala" title="Iguala">Iguala</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_Federal_Police" title="Mexican Federal Police">Mexican Federal Police</a> were dissolved in 2019 by a constitutional amendment during the administration of President López Obrador and the Mexican <a href="/wiki/National_Guard_(Mexico)" title="National Guard (Mexico)">National Guard</a> established, amalgamating units of the Federal Police, Military Police, and Naval Police.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[200]</a></sup> As of 2022, the National Guard is an estimated at 110,000. López Obrador has increasingly used military forces for domestic law enforcement, particularly against drug cartels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[201]</a></sup>  There have been serious abuses of power have been reported in security operations in the southern part of the country and in indigenous communities and poor urban neighborhoods. The National Human Rights Commission has had little impact in reversing this trend, engaging mostly in documentation but failing to use its powers to issue public condemnations to the officials who ignore its recommendations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[202]</a></sup>  Most Mexicans have low confidence in the police or the judicial system, and therefore, few crimes are actually reported by the citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brit-mex_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-206">[203]</a></sup> There have been public demonstrations of outrage against what is considered a culture of <a href="/wiki/Impunity" title="Impunity">impunity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>Crime and human rights violations in Mexico have been criticized, including enforced disappearances (kidnappings), abuses against migrants, extrajudicial killings, gender-based violence, especially <a href="/wiki/Femicide" title="Femicide">femicide</a>, and attacks on journalists and human rights advocatess.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[205]</a></sup> 
A 2020 report by the <a href="/wiki/British_Broadcasting_Company" title="British Broadcasting Company">BBC</a> gives statistics on crime in Mexico, with 10.7 million households with at least one victim of crime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[206]</a></sup> 
As of May 2022, 100,000 people are officially listed as missing, most since 2007 when President Calderón attempted to stop the drug cartels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[207]</a></sup> Drug cartels remain a major issue in Mexico, with a proliferation of smaller cartels when larger ones are broken up and increasingly the use of more sophisticated military equipment and tactics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[209]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Felipe_Calder%C3%B3n" title="Felipe Calderón">Felipe Calderón</a> (2006–12) made eradicating organized crime a top priority by deploying military personnel to cities where drug cartels operate, a move criticized by the opposition parties and the National Human Rights Commission for escalating the violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[210]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" title="Mexican Drug War">Mexico's drug war</a>, ongoing since 2006, has left over 120,000 dead and perhaps another 37,000 missing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cfrdeaths_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-cfrdeaths-37">[34]</a></sup> Mexican cartels have recently been identified as using the Chinese-sourced synthetic opiate <a href="/wiki/Fentanyl" title="Fentanyl">fentanyl</a>, which has caused many drug overdoses in the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[211]</a></sup> China is identified as being involved more generally in organized crime in Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[212]</a></sup>  Mexico's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">National Geography and Statistics Institute</a> estimated that in 2014, one-fifth of Mexicans were victims of some sort of crime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[213]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2014_Iguala_mass_kidnapping" title="2014 Iguala mass kidnapping">mass kidnapping of 43 students</a> in <a href="/wiki/Iguala" title="Iguala">Iguala</a> on 26 September 2014 triggered nationwide protests against the government's weak response to the disappearances and widespread corruption that gives free rein to criminal organizations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[214]</a></sup> More than 100 journalists and <a href="/wiki/List_of_journalists_and_media_workers_killed_in_Mexico" title="List of journalists and media workers killed in Mexico">media workers have been killed or disappeared</a> since 2000, and most of these crimes remained unsolved, improperly investigated, and with few perpetrators arrested and convicted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[216]</a></sup> Since President López Obrador became president in 2018, the number of journalists' murders has increased exponentially.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[219]</a></sup> The U.S. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_of_State" title="Department of State">Department of State</a> warns its citizens to exercise increased caution when traveling in Mexico, issuing travel advisories on its website.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[220]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Mexico" title="Administrative divisions of Mexico">Administrative divisions of Mexico</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/States_of_Mexico" title="States of Mexico">States of Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Mexico" title="Municipalities of Mexico">Municipalities of Mexico</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_state_legislatures" title="List of Mexican state legislatures">List of Mexican state legislatures</a></div>
<p>The boundaries and constituent units of Mexico evolved over time from its colonial-era origins. Central America peacefully separated from Mexico after independence in 1821. Yucatán was briefly an independent republic. Texas separated in the <a href="/wiki/Texas_Revolution" title="Texas Revolution">Texas Revolution</a> and when it was annexed to the U.S. in 1845, it set the stage for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican-American_War" title="Mexican-American War">Mexican-American War</a> and major territorial loss to the U.S. The sale of northern territory known in the U.S. as the <a href="/wiki/Gadsden_Purchase" title="Gadsden Purchase">Gadsden Purchase</a> was the last loss of Mexican territory. The United Mexican States are a federation of 31 free and sovereign states, which form a union that exercises a degree of jurisdiction over <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thought_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-thought-224">[221]</a></sup> Each state has its own constitution, <a href="/wiki/Congress" title="Congress">congress</a>, and a judiciary, and its citizens elect by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct_vote" title="Direct vote">direct voting</a> a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_state_governors" title="List of Mexican state governors">governor</a> for a six-year term, and representatives to their respective unicameral state congresses for three-year terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico City is a special political division that belongs to the federation as a whole and not to a particular state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thought_224-1"><a href="#cite_note-thought-224">[221]</a></sup> Formerly known as the Federal District, its autonomy was previously limited relative to that of the states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[223]</a></sup> It dropped this designation in 2016 and is in the process of achieving greater political autonomy by becoming a federal entity with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitutional_Assembly_of_Mexico_City" title="Constitutional Assembly of Mexico City">its own constitution</a> and congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[224]</a></sup> The states are divided into <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Mexico" title="Municipalities of Mexico">municipalities</a>, the smallest administrative political entity in the country, governed by a <a href="/wiki/Mayor" title="Mayor">mayor or municipal president</a> (<span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">presidente municipal</i></span>), elected by its residents by plurality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<center>
