<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Mexico" title="Economy of Mexico">Economy of Mexico</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico" title="Economic history of Mexico">Economic history of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Mexico_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/220px-Mexico_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Mexico_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/330px-Mexico_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Mexico_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/440px-Mexico_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Mexico's exports. The country has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_economic_complexity" title="List of countries by economic complexity">most complex economy</a> in Latin America.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_City_(2018)_-_508.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Mexico_City_%282018%29_-_508.jpg/220px-Mexico_City_%282018%29_-_508.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Mexico_City_%282018%29_-_508.jpg/330px-Mexico_City_%282018%29_-_508.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Mexico_City_%282018%29_-_508.jpg/440px-Mexico_City_%282018%29_-_508.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_City_(2018)_-_508.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mexican_Stock_Exchange" title="Mexican Stock Exchange">Mexican Stock Exchange</a> building, in <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a></div></div></div>
<p>As of April 2018, Mexico has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">15th largest</a> nominal GDP (US$1.15 trillion)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-invest_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-invest-229">[226]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (US$2.45 trillion). GDP annual average growth was 2.9% in 2016 and 2% in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-invest_229-1"><a href="#cite_note-invest-229">[226]</a></sup> Agriculture has comprised 4% of the economy over the last two decades, while industry contributes 33% (mostly automotive, oil, and electronics) and services (notably financial services and tourism) contribute 63%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-invest_229-2"><a href="#cite_note-invest-229">[226]</a></sup> Mexico's GDP in PPP per capita was US$18,714.05. The World Bank reported in 2009 that the country's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gross_National_Income" title="Gross National Income">Gross National Income</a> in market exchange rates was the second highest in Latin America, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> at US$1,830.392 billion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GNI_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-GNI-230">[227]</a></sup> which led to the highest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gross_National_Income" title="Gross National Income">income per capita</a> in the region at $15,311.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GNIPC_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-GNIPC-232">[229]</a></sup> Mexico is now firmly established as an upper middle-income country. After the slowdown of 2001 the country has recovered and has grown 4.2, 3.0 and 4.8 percent in 2004, 2005 and 2006,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[230]</a></sup> even though it is considered to be well below Mexico's potential growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hufbauer_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hufbauer-234">[231]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> predicts growth rates of 2.3% and 2.7% for 2018 and 2019, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-invest_229-3"><a href="#cite_note-invest-229">[226]</a></sup> By 2050, Mexico could potentially become the world's fifth or seventh largest economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[233]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although multiple international organizations coincide and classify Mexico as an upper middle income country, or a middle class country<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BloombergEcon_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-BloombergEcon-238">[235]</a></sup> Mexico's <a href="/wiki/National_Council_for_the_Evaluation_of_Social_Development_Policy_(CONEVAL)" title="National Council for the Evaluation of Social Development Policy (CONEVAL)">National Council for the Evaluation of Social Development Policy</a> (CONEVAL), which is the organization in charge to measure the country's poverty reports that a huge percentage of Mexico's population lives in poverty. According to said council, from 2006 to 2010 (year on which the CONEVAL published its first nationwide report of poverty) the portion of Mexicans who live in poverty rose from 18%–19%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[236]</a></sup> to 46% (52 million people).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CONEVAL_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-CONEVAL-240">[237]</a></sup> However, rather than Mexico's economy crashing, international economists attribute the huge increase in the percentage of population living below the country's poverty line to the CONEVAL using new standards to define it, as now besides people who lives below the economic welfare line, people who lacks at least one "social need" such as complete education, access to healthcare, access to regular food, housing services and goods, social security etc. were considered to be living in poverty (several countries do collect information regarding the persistence of said vulnerabilities on their population, but Mexico is the only one that classifies people lacking one or more of those needs as living below its national poverty line). Said economists do point out that the percentage of people living in poverty according to Mexico's national poverty line is around 40 times higher than the one reported by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank's</a> international poverty line (with said difference being the biggest in the world) and ponder if it would not be better for countries in the situation of Mexico to adopt internationalized standards to measure poverty so the numbers obtained could be used to make accurate international comparisons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[238]</a></sup> According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>'s own poverty line (defined as the percentage of a country's population who earns 60%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[239]</a></sup> or less of the national median income) 20% of Mexico's population lives in a situation of poverty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[240]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:San_Pedro_,Nuevo_Le%C3%B3n,_M%C3%A9xico.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="560" data-file-width="420" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/San_Pedro_%2CNuevo_Le%C3%B3n%2C_M%C3%A9xico.jpg/220px-San_Pedro_%2CNuevo_Le%C3%B3n%2C_M%C3%A9xico.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/San_Pedro_%2CNuevo_Le%C3%B3n%2C_M%C3%A9xico.jpg/330px-San_Pedro_%2CNuevo_Le%C3%B3n%2C_M%C3%A9xico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/San_Pedro_%2CNuevo_Le%C3%B3n%2C_M%C3%A9xico.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:San_Pedro_,Nuevo_Le%C3%B3n,_M%C3%A9xico.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Skyscraper" title="Skyscraper">Skyscrapers</a> in <a href="/wiki/San_Pedro_Garza_Garc%C3%ADa" title="San Pedro Garza García">San Pedro Garza García</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuevo_Le%C3%B3n" title="Nuevo León">Nuevo León</a></div></div></div>
<p>Among the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> countries, Mexico has the second-highest degree of economic disparity between the extremely poor and extremely rich, after Chile – although it has been falling over the last decade, being one of few countries in which this is the case.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[241]</a></sup> The bottom ten percent in the income hierarchy disposes of 1.36% of the country's resources, whereas the upper ten percent dispose of almost 36%. The OECD also notes that Mexico's budgeted expenses for poverty alleviation and social development is only about a third of the OECD average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECDREFORMA_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECDREFORMA-245">[242]</a></sup> This is also reflected by the fact that infant mortality in Mexico is three times higher than the average among OECD nations whereas its literacy levels are in the median range of OECD nations. Nevertheless, according to <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a>, by 2050 Mexico will have the 5th largest economy in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[243]</a></sup> According to a 2008 UN report the average income in a typical urbanized area of Mexico was $26,654, while the average income in rural areas just miles away was only $8,403.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[244]</a></sup> Daily minimum wages are set annually being set at $102.68 <a href="/wiki/Mexican_peso" title="Mexican peso">Mexican pesos</a> (US$5.40) in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[245]</a></sup> All of the indices of social development for the Mexican Indigenous population are considerably lower than the national average, which is motive of concern for the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inegi.org.mx_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-inegi.org.mx-249">[246]</a></sup>
</p><p>The electronics industry of Mexico has grown enormously within the last decade. Mexico has the sixth largest electronics industry in the world after <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, United States, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. Mexico is the second-largest exporter of electronics to the United States where it exported $71.4 billion worth of electronics in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-250">[247]</a></sup> The Mexican electronics industry is dominated by the manufacture and OEM design of televisions, displays, computers, mobile phones, circuit boards, semiconductors, electronic appliances, communications equipment and LCD modules. The Mexican electronics industry grew 20% between 2010 and 2011, up from its constant growth rate of 17% between 2003 and 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_250-1"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-250">[247]</a></sup> Currently electronics represent 30% of Mexico's exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_250-2"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-250">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico produces the most automobiles of any North American nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[248]</a></sup> The industry produces technologically complex components and engages in some research and development activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gereffi_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-252">[249]</a></sup> The "Big Three" (<a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chrysler" title="Chrysler">Chrysler</a>) have been operating in Mexico since the 1930s, while <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nissan" title="Nissan">Nissan</a> built their plants in the 1960s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hufbauer_Auto_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hufbauer_Auto-253">[250]</a></sup> In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puebla,_Puebla" title="Puebla, Puebla">Puebla</a> alone, 70 industrial part-makers cluster around Volkswagen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gereffi_252-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-252">[249]</a></sup> In the 2010s expansion of the sector was surging. In 2014 alone, more than $10 billion in investment was committed. In September 2016 Kia motors opened a $1 billion factory in <a href="/wiki/Nuevo_Le%C3%B3n" title="Nuevo León">Nuevo León</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[251]</a></sup> with Audi also opening an assembling plant in Puebla the same year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[252]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nissan" title="Nissan">Nissan</a> currently have plants in construction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KiaMexico_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-KiaMexico-256">[253]</a></sup> The domestic car industry is represented by <a href="/wiki/DINA_S.A." title="DINA S.A.">DINA S.A.</a>, which has built buses and trucks since 1962,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[254]</a></sup> and the new <a href="/wiki/Mastretta" title="Mastretta">Mastretta</a> company that builds the high-performance <a href="/wiki/Mastretta_MXT" title="Mastretta MXT">Mastretta MXT</a> sports car.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[255]</a></sup> In 2006, trade with the United States and Canada accounted for almost 50% of Mexico's exports and 45% of its imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia.gov_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-15">[12]</a></sup> During the first three quarters of 2010, the United States had a $46.0 billion <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_deficit" title="Trade deficit">trade deficit</a> with Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[256]</a></sup> In August 2010 Mexico surpassed France to become the 9th largest holder of US debt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[257]</a></sup> The commercial and financial dependence on the US is a cause for concern.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>The remittances from Mexican citizens working in the United States account are significant; after dipping during the after the 2008 <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a> and again during <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Covid_pandemic" title="Covid pandemic">Covid pandemic</a> in 2021 they are topping other sources of foreign income.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[259]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[260]</a></sup> Remittances are directed to Mexico by direct links from a U.S. government banking program.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[261]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communications">Communications</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Mexico" title="Telecommunications in Mexico">Telecommunications in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_City_2015_081.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5184" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Mexico_City_2015_081.jpg/170px-Mexico_City_2015_081.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Mexico_City_2015_081.jpg/255px-Mexico_City_2015_081.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Mexico_City_2015_081.jpg/340px-Mexico_City_2015_081.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_City_2015_081.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Telmex" title="Telmex">Telmex</a> Tower, Mexico City.</div></div></div>
<p>The telecommunications industry is mostly dominated by <a href="/wiki/Telmex" title="Telmex">Telmex</a> (<i>Teléfonos de México</i>), previously a government monopoly privatized in 1990. By 2006, Telmex had expanded its operations to Colombia, Peru, Chile, Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay, and the United States. Other players in the domestic industry are <a href="/wiki/Axtel" title="Axtel">Axtel</a>, Maxcom, Alestra, Marcatel, AT&amp;T Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-budde_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-budde-265">[262]</a></sup> Because of Mexican <a href="/wiki/Orography" title="Orography">orography</a>, providing a landline telephone service at remote mountainous areas is expensive, and the penetration of line-phones per capita is low compared to other Latin American countries, at 40 percent; however, 82% of Mexicans over the age of 14 own a mobile phone. Mobile telephony has the advantage of reaching all areas at a lower cost, and the total number of mobile lines is almost two times that of landlines, with an estimation of 63 million lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ciacom_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-ciacom-266">[263]</a></sup> The telecommunication industry is regulated by the government through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cofetel" title="Cofetel">Cofetel</a> (<i>Comisión Federal de Telecomunicaciones</i>).
</p><p>The Mexican satellite system is domestic and operates 120 earth stations. There is also extensive microwave radio relay network and considerable use of fiber-optic and coaxial cable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ciacom_266-1"><a href="#cite_note-ciacom-266">[263]</a></sup> Mexican satellites are operated by <i>Satélites Mexicanos</i> (<a href="/wiki/Satmex" title="Satmex">Satmex</a>), a private company, leader in Latin America and servicing both North and South America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[264]</a></sup> It offers broadcast, telephone and telecommunication services to 37 countries in the Americas, from Canada to <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>. Through business partnerships Satmex provides high-speed connectivity to ISPs and Digital Broadcast Services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[265]</a></sup> Satmex maintains its own satellite fleet with most of the fleet being designed and built in Mexico. Major players in the broadcasting industry are <a href="/wiki/Televisa" title="Televisa">Televisa</a>, the largest Mexican media company in the Spanish-speaking world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-269">[266]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Imagen_Televisi%C3%B3n" title="Imagen Televisión">Imagen Televisión</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Mexico" title="Electricity sector in Mexico">Electricity sector in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I,_Fase_II.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1104" data-file-width="1654" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/220px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/330px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/440px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I,_Fase_II.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Central Eólica Sureste I, Fase II in <a href="/wiki/Oaxaca" title="Oaxaca">Oaxaca</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Energy production in Mexico is managed by the state-owned companies <a href="/wiki/Comisi%C3%B3n_Federal_de_Electricidad" title="Comisión Federal de Electricidad">Federal Commission of Electricity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pemex" title="Pemex">Pemex</a>. Pemex, the public company in charge of exploration, extraction, transportation and marketing of crude oil and natural gas, as well as the refining and distribution of petroleum products and petrochemicals, is one of the largest companies in the world by revenue, making US$86 billion in sales a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fortune_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-fortune-271">[268]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[269]</a></sup> Mexico is the sixth-largest oil producer in the world, with 3.7 million barrels per day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[270]</a></sup> In 1980 oil exports accounted for 61.6% of total exports; by 2000 it was only 7.3%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gereffi_252-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-252">[249]</a></sup> The largest hydro plant in Mexico is the 2,400 MW <a href="/wiki/Chicoas%C3%A9n_Dam" title="Chicoasén Dam">Manuel Moreno Torres Dam</a> in Chicoasén, <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Grijalva_River" title="Grijalva River">Grijalva River</a>. This is the world's fourth most productive hydroelectric plant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EIA_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-EIA-274">[271]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico is the country with the world's third largest solar potential.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-S&amp;G_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-S&amp;G-275">[272]</a></sup> The country's gross solar potential is estimated at 5kWh/m2 daily, which corresponds to 50 times national electricity generation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ER_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-ER-276">[273]</a></sup> Currently, there is over 1 million square meters of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Solar_thermal" title="Solar thermal">solar thermal</a> panels<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SENER_2009b_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-SENER_2009b-277">[274]</a></sup> installed in Mexico, while in 2005, there were 115,000 square meters of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Solar_PV" title="Solar PV">solar PV</a> (photo-voltaic). It is expected that in 2012 there will be 1,8 million square meters of installed solar thermal panels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SENER_2009b_277-1"><a href="#cite_note-SENER_2009b-277">[274]</a></sup> The project named <a href="/wiki/SEGH-CFE_1" title="SEGH-CFE 1">SEGH-CFE 1</a>, located in Puerto Libertad, Sonora, Northwest of Mexico, will have capacity of 46.8 MW from an array of 187,200 solar panels when complete in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sonora_Energy_Group_Hermosillo_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sonora_Energy_Group_Hermosillo-278">[275]</a></sup> All of the electricity will be sold directly to the CFE and absorbed into the utility's transmission system for distribution throughout their existing network. At an installed capacity of 46.8 MWp, when complete in 2013, the project will be the first utility scale project of its kind in Mexico and the largest solar project of any kind in Latin America.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Mexico" title="History of science and technology in Mexico">History of science and technology in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Large_Millimeter_Telescope_Mexico.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="377" data-file-width="316" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Large_Millimeter_Telescope_Mexico.jpg/170px-Large_Millimeter_Telescope_Mexico.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Large_Millimeter_Telescope_Mexico.jpg/255px-Large_Millimeter_Telescope_Mexico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/99/Large_Millimeter_Telescope_Mexico.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Large_Millimeter_Telescope_Mexico.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Large_Millimeter_Telescope" title="Large Millimeter Telescope">Large Millimeter Telescope</a> in <a href="/wiki/Puebla" title="Puebla">Puebla</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a> was officially established in 1910,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[276]</a></sup> and the university became one of the most important institutes of higher learning in Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[277]</a></sup> UNAM provides world class education in science, medicine, and engineering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[278]</a></sup> Many scientific institutes and new institutes of higher learning, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Polytechnic_Institute" title="National Polytechnic Institute">National Polytechnic Institute</a> (founded in 1936),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[279]</a></sup> were established during the first half of the 20th century. Most of the new research institutes were created within UNAM. Twelve institutes were integrated into UNAM from 1929 to 1973.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[280]</a></sup> In 1959, the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Mexican Academy of Sciences">Mexican Academy of Sciences</a> was created to coordinate scientific efforts between academics.
</p><p>In 1995, the Mexican chemist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mario_J._Molina" title="Mario J. Molina">Mario J. Molina</a> shared the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> with <a href="/wiki/Paul_J._Crutzen" title="Paul J. Crutzen">Paul J. Crutzen</a> and <a href="/wiki/F._Sherwood_Rowland" title="F. Sherwood Rowland">F. Sherwood Rowland</a> for their work in atmospheric chemistry, particularly concerning the formation and decomposition of ozone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[281]</a></sup> Molina, an alumnus of UNAM, became the first Mexican citizen to win the Nobel Prize in science.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[282]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, the largest scientific project being developed in Mexico was the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Large_Millimeter_Telescope" title="Large Millimeter Telescope">Large Millimeter Telescope</a> (Gran Telescopio Milimétrico, GMT), the world's largest and most sensitive single-aperture telescope in its frequency range.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[283]</a></sup> It was designed to observe regions of space obscured by stellar dust. Mexico was ranked 55th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021, up from 56th in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[287]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Mexico" title="Tourism in Mexico">Tourism in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="832" data-file-width="1248" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg/220px-Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg/330px-Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg/440px-Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Canc%C3%BAn" title="Cancún">Cancún</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Riviera_Maya" title="Riviera Maya">Riviera Maya</a> is the most visited region in Latin America</div></div></div>
<p>As of 2017, Mexico was the 6th most visited country in the world and had the 15th highest income from tourism in the world which is also the highest in Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2018_Edition_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2018_Edition-291">[288]</a></sup> The vast majority of tourists come to Mexico from the United States and Canada followed by Europe and Asia. A smaller number also come from other Latin American countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[289]</a></sup> In the 2017 <a href="/wiki/Travel_and_Tourism_Competitiveness_Report" title="Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report">Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report</a>, Mexico was ranked 22nd in the world, which was 3rd in the Americas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[290]</a></sup>
</p><p>The coastlines of Mexico harbor many stretches of beaches that are frequented by sunbathers and other visitors. <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico#Article_27" title="Constitution of Mexico">According to national law</a>, the entirety of the coastlines are under federal ownership, that is, all beaches in the country are <a href="/wiki/Public_property" title="Public property">public</a>. On the Yucatán peninsula, one of the most popular beach destinations is the resort town of <a href="/wiki/Canc%C3%BAn" title="Cancún">Cancún</a>, especially among <a href="/wiki/University" title="University">university</a> <a href="/wiki/Student" title="Student">students</a> during <a href="/wiki/Spring_break" title="Spring break">spring break</a>. Just offshore is the beach island of <a href="/wiki/Isla_Mujeres" title="Isla Mujeres">Isla Mujeres</a>, and to the east is the <a href="/wiki/Isla_Holbox" title="Isla Holbox">Isla Holbox</a>. To the south of Cancun is the coastal strip called <a href="/wiki/Riviera_Maya" title="Riviera Maya">Riviera Maya</a> which includes the beach town of <a href="/wiki/Playa_del_Carmen" title="Playa del Carmen">Playa del Carmen</a> and the ecological parks of <a href="/wiki/Xcaret" title="Xcaret">Xcaret</a> and Xel-Há. A day trip to the south of Cancún is the historic port of <a href="/wiki/Tulum" title="Tulum">Tulum</a>. In addition to its beaches, the town of Tulum is notable for its cliff-side <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Mayan</a> ruins. On the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific" title="Pacific">Pacific</a> coast is the notable tourist destination of <a href="/wiki/Acapulco" title="Acapulco">Acapulco</a>. Once the destination for the rich and famous, the beaches have become crowded and the shores are now home to many multi-story hotels and vendors. Acapulco is home to renowned cliff divers: trained divers who leap from the side of a vertical cliff into the surf below. At the southern tip of the <a href="/wiki/Baja_California_peninsula" title="Baja California peninsula">Baja California peninsula</a> is the resort town of <a href="/wiki/Cabo_San_Lucas" title="Cabo San Lucas">Cabo San Lucas</a>, a town noted for its beaches and <a href="/wiki/Marlin" title="Marlin">marlin</a> <a href="/wiki/Fishing" title="Fishing">fishing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[291]</a></sup> Further north along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sea_of_Cort%C3%A9s" title="Sea of Cortés">Sea of Cortés</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%ADa_Concepci%C3%B3n,_Baja_California_Sur" title="Bahía Concepción, Baja California Sur">Bahía de La Concepción</a>, another beach town known for its sports fishing. Closer to the United States border is the weekend draw of <a href="/wiki/San_Felipe,_Baja_California" title="San Felipe, Baja California">San Felipe, Baja California</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Mexico" title="Transportation in Mexico">Transportation in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Puente_Baluarte_03.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Puente_Baluarte_03.jpg/220px-Puente_Baluarte_03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Puente_Baluarte_03.jpg/330px-Puente_Baluarte_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Puente_Baluarte_03.jpg/440px-Puente_Baluarte_03.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Puente_Baluarte_03.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Baluarte_Bridge" title="Baluarte Bridge">Baluarte Bridge</a> was the highest cable-stayed bridge in the world, the fifth-highest bridge overall and is the highest bridge in the Americas.</div></div></div>
<p>The roadway network in Mexico is extensive and all areas in the country are covered by it. The roadway network in Mexico has an extent of 366,095 km (227,481 mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sctroad_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-295">[292]</a></sup> of which 116,802 km (72,577 mi) are paved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sctroad-2_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-2-296">[293]</a></sup> Of these, 10,474 km (6,508 mi) are multi-lane <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">expressways</a>: 9,544 km (5,930 mi) are four-lane highways and the rest have 6 or more lanes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sctroad-2_296-1"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-2-296">[293]</a></sup>
</p><p>Starting in the late nineteenth century, Mexico was one of the first Latin American countries to promote railway development,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brit-mex_206-1"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-206">[203]</a></sup> and the network covers 30,952 km (19,233 mi). The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Communications_and_Transportation_(Mexico)" title="Secretariat of Communications and Transportation (Mexico)">Secretary of Communications and Transport</a> of Mexico proposed a high-speed rail link that will transport its passengers from <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a> to <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jalisco" title="Jalisco">Jalisco</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-azcentral.com_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-azcentral.com-297">[294]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[295]</a></sup> The train, which will travel at 300 kilometers per hour (190 miles per hour),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-systra.com_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-systra.com-299">[296]</a></sup> will allow passengers to travel from Mexico City to Guadalajara in just 2 hours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-systra.com_299-1"><a href="#cite_note-systra.com-299">[296]</a></sup> The whole project was projected to cost 240 billion <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MXN" title="MXN">pesos</a>, or about 25 billion US$<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-azcentral.com_297-1"><a href="#cite_note-azcentral.com-297">[294]</a></sup> and is being paid for jointly by the Mexican government and the local private sector including the wealthiest man in the world, Mexico's billionaire business tycoon <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Slim" title="Carlos Slim">Carlos Slim</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[297]</a></sup> The government of the state of <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Yucatán">Yucatán</a> is also funding the construction of a high speed line connecting the cities of <a href="/wiki/Cozumel" title="Cozumel">Cozumel</a> to <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida,_Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Mérida, Yucatán">Mérida</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chichen_Itza" title="Chichen Itza">Chichen Itza</a> and Cancún.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[298]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico has 233 airports with paved runways; of these, 35 carry 97% of the passenger traffic.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_International_Airport" title="Mexico City International Airport">Mexico City International Airport</a> remains the busiest in Latin America and the 36th busiest in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[299]</a></sup> transporting 45 million passengers a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aicmstats_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-aicmstats-303">[300]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Mexico" title="Demographics of Mexico">Demographics of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_estados_densidad.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="680" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Mexico_estados_densidad.svg/220px-Mexico_estados_densidad.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Mexico_estados_densidad.svg/330px-Mexico_estados_densidad.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Mexico_estados_densidad.svg/440px-Mexico_estados_densidad.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_estados_densidad.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mexican states by population density</div></div></div>
<p>Throughout the 19th century, the population of Mexico had barely doubled. This trend continued during the first two decades of the 20th century, and even in the 1921 census there was a loss of about 1 million inhabitants. The phenomenon can be explained because during the decade from 1910 to 1921 the Mexican Revolution took place. The growth rate increased dramatically between the 1930s and the 1980s, when the country registered growth rates of over 3% (1950–1980). The Mexican population doubled in twenty years, and at that rate it was expected that by 2000 there would be 120 million Mexicans. Life expectancy went from 36 years (in 1895) to 72 years (in the year 2000). According to estimations made by Mexico's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">National Geography and Statistics Institute</a>, is estimated in 2022 to be 129,150,971<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[301]</a></sup> as of 2017 Mexico had 123.5 million inhabitants<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[302]</a></sup> making it the most populous Spanish-speaking country in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spanishhistory_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-Spanishhistory-306">[303]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnicity_and_race">Ethnicity and race</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Casta_painting_all.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="1419" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Casta_painting_all.jpg/170px-Casta_painting_all.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Casta_painting_all.jpg/255px-Casta_painting_all.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Casta_painting_all.jpg/340px-Casta_painting_all.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Casta_painting_all.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Las castas</i></span>. Casta painting showing 16 racial groupings, 18th century, <span title="Spanish-language text"><span lang="es" style="font-style: normal;">Museo Nacional del Virreinato</span></span>, <span title="Nahuatl languages collective text"><span lang="nah" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Tepotzotl%C3%A1n" title="Tepotzotlán">Tepotzotlán</a></span></span>, Mexico.</div></div></div>
<p>Despite being highly diverse, research on Mexican ethnicity has felt the impact of nationalist discourses on identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Knight,_Alan_1990._pp._78_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-Knight,_Alan_1990._pp._78-307">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated115_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated115-308">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-census-309">[306]</a></sup> which saw their peak in the decade of the 1930s, when the government declared all Mexicans to be Mestizos, with the only distinction being whether a person was culturally indigenous or not, living in an indigenous community and or speaking an indigenous language or both.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES-310">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-redalyc_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-redalyc-311">[308]</a></sup> Even then, across the years the government has used different criteria to count Indigenous peoples, with each of them returning considerably different numbers ranging from 6.1%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-3"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup> to 23% of the country's population. It is not until very recently that the Mexican government began conducting surveys that consider other ethnic groups that live in the country such as Afro-Mexicans who amount to 2% of Mexico's population<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-4"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup> or White Mexicans<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ElUniversal_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-ElUniversal-312">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forbes-313">[310]</a></sup> who amount to 47% of Mexico's population (with the criteria being based on appearance rather than on self-declared ancestry).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017-314">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-conapred.org.mx_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-conapred.org.mx-315">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DISC-RACIAL_2011_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-DISC-RACIAL_2011-316">[313]</a></sup> Less numerous groups in Mexico such as Asians and Middle Easterners are also accounted for, with numbers of around 1% each. While Mestizos are a prominent ethnic group in contemporary Mexico, the subjective and ever-changing definition of this category have led to its estimations being imprecise, having been observed that many Mexicans do not identify as Mestizos,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[314]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clute_Journals_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-Clute_Journals-318">[315]</a></sup> favoring instead ethnoracial labels such as White or Indigenous due to having more consistent and "static" definitions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mestizajeenmexico_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-mestizajeenmexico-319">[316]</a></sup>
</p><p>The total percentage of Mexico's <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_Mexico" title="Indigenous peoples of Mexico">indigenous peoples</a> tends to vary depending on the criteria used by the government in its censuses: if the ability to speak an indigenous language is used as the criterion to define a person as indigenous, it is 6.1%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-5"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inegiindigenous_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-inegiindigenous-320">[317]</a></sup> if racial self-identification is used, it is 14.9%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDI1_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-CDI1-321">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[d]</a></sup> and if people who consider themselves part indigenous are also included, it amounts to 23%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-beta.inegi.org.mx_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-beta.inegi.org.mx-325">[321]</a></sup> Nonetheless, all the censuses conclude that the majority of Mexico's indigenous population is concentrated in rural areas of the southern and south-eastern Mexican states,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[322]</a></sup> with the highest percentages being found in Yucatán (59% of the population), Oaxaca (48%), Quintana Roo (39%), Chiapas (28%), and Campeche (27%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inegi.org.mx_249-1"><a href="#cite_note-inegi.org.mx-249">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDI_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-CDI-327">[323]</a></sup>
</p><p>Similarly to Mestizo and indigenous peoples, estimates of the percentage of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexicans_of_European_descent" title="Mexicans of European descent">European-descended Mexicans</a> vary considerably depending on the criteria used: recent nationwide field surveys that account for different phenotypical traits (hair color, skin color etc.) report a percentage between 18%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[324]</a></sup>-23%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[325]</a></sup> if the criterion is the presence of <a href="/wiki/Blond" title="Blond">blond hair</a>, and of 47% if the criterion is skin color, with the later surveys having been conducted by Mexico's government itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017_314-1"><a href="#cite_note-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017-314">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-conapred.org.mx_315-1"><a href="#cite_note-conapred.org.mx-315">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DISC-RACIAL_2011_316-1"><a href="#cite_note-DISC-RACIAL_2011-316">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ENADIS2017_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-ENADIS2017-330">[326]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MMSI2_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-MMSI2-331">[327]</a></sup> While, during the colonial era, most of the European migration into Mexico was <a href="/wiki/Spaniards_in_Mexico" title="Spaniards in Mexico">Spanish</a>, in the 19th and 20th centuries, a substantial number of non-Spanish Europeans immigrated to the country,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fnavarrete_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-fnavarrete-332">[328]</a></sup> with Europeans often being the most numerous ethnic group in colonial Mexican cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnsayospoblaciónMéxico_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-EnsayospoblaciónMéxico-333">[329]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[330]</a></sup> Nowadays, Mexico's northern and western regions have the highest percentages of European populations, with the majority of the people not having native admixture or being of predominantly European ancestry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UnitedStatesandMexico_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-UnitedStatesandMexico-335">[331]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Afro-Mexicans" title="Afro-Mexicans">Afro-Mexican</a> population (2,576,213 individuals as of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-6"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encuesta_Intercensal_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encuesta_Intercensal-336">[332]</a></sup> is an ethnic group made up of descendants of Colonial-era slaves and recent immigrants of sub-Saharan African descent. Mexico had an active slave trade during the colonial period, and some 200,000 Africans were taken there, primarily in the 17th century. The creation of a national Mexican identity, especially after the Mexican Revolution, emphasized Mexico's indigenous and European past; it passively eliminated the African ancestors and contributions. Most of the African-descended population was absorbed into the surrounding Mestizo (mixed European/indigenous) and indigenous populations through unions among the groups. Evidence of this long history of intermarriage with Mestizo and indigenous Mexicans is also expressed in the fact that, in the 2015 inter-census, 64.9% (896,829) of Afro-Mexicans also identified as indigenous. It was also reported that 7.4% of Afro-Mexicans speak an indigenous language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-7"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[333]</a></sup> The states with the highest self-report of Afro-Mexicans were Guerrero (8.6% of the population), Oaxaca (4.7%) and Baja California Sur (3.3%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-8"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[334]</a></sup> Afro-Mexican culture is strongest in the communities of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Costa_Chica_of_Oaxaca" title="Costa Chica of Oaxaca">Costa Chica of Oaxaca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Costa_Chica_of_Guerrero" title="Costa Chica of Guerrero">Costa Chica of Guerrero</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Geographic_ancestry_distribution_of_Mexico.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="820" data-file-width="3505" decoding="async" height="103" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Geographic_ancestry_distribution_of_Mexico.png/440px-Geographic_ancestry_distribution_of_Mexico.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Geographic_ancestry_distribution_of_Mexico.png/660px-Geographic_ancestry_distribution_of_Mexico.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Geographic_ancestry_distribution_of_Mexico.png/880px-Geographic_ancestry_distribution_of_Mexico.png 2x" width="440"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Geographic_ancestry_distribution_of_Mexico.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Regional variation of ancestry according to a study made by Ruiz-Linares in 2014, each dot represents a volunteer, with most coming from south Mexico and Mexico City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ruiz-Linares_et_al,_2014_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ruiz-Linares_et_al,_2014-339">[335]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>During the early 20th century, a substantial number of <a href="/wiki/Arab_Mexicans" title="Arab Mexicans">Arabs</a> (mostly <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Christians</a>)<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> began arriving from the crumbling <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The largest group were the Lebanese and an estimated 400,000 Mexicans have some <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_Mexicans" title="Lebanese Mexicans">Lebanese ancestry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[336]</a></sup>
</p><p>Smaller ethnic groups in Mexico include <a href="/wiki/Asian_Mexicans" title="Asian Mexicans">South and East Asians</a>, present since the colonial era. During the colonial era, Asians were termed <i>Chino</i> (regardless of ethnicity), and arrived as merchants, artisans and slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seijas_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-Seijas-341">[337]</a></sup> A study by Juan Esteban Rodríguez, a graduate student at the National Laboratory of Genomics for Biodiversity, indicated that up to one third of people sampled from <a href="/wiki/Guerrero" title="Guerrero">Guerrero</a> state had significantly more Asian ancestry than most Mexicans, primarily <a href="/wiki/Filipino_immigration_to_Mexico" title="Filipino immigration to Mexico">Filipino</a> or <a href="/wiki/Native_Indonesians" title="Native Indonesians">Indonesian</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[339]</a></sup> Modern Asian immigration began in the late 19th century, and at one point in the early 20th century, the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_immigration_to_Mexico" title="Chinese immigration to Mexico">Chinese</a> were the second largest immigrant group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[340]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Mexico" title="Languages of Mexico">Languages of Mexico</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> is the <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> national language spoken by the vast majority of the population, making Mexico the world's most populous <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">Hispanophone</a> country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spanishhistory_306-1"><a href="#cite_note-Spanishhistory-306">[303]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Spanish" title="Mexican Spanish">Mexican Spanish</a> refers to the <a href="/wiki/Variety_(linguistics)" title="Variety (linguistics)">varieties</a> of the language spoken in the country, which differ from one region to another in sound, structure, and vocabulary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-346">[342]</a></sup> In general, Mexican Spanish does not make any phonetic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seseo" title="Seseo">distinction among the letters <i>s</i> and <i>z</i></a>, as well as <i>c</i> when preceding the vowels <i>e</i> and <i>i</i>, as opposed to <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_Spanish" title="Peninsular Spanish">Peninsular Spanish</a>. The letters <i>b</i> and <i>v</i> have the same pronunciation as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_346-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-346">[342]</a></sup> Furthermore, the usage of <i><a href="/wiki/Voseo" title="Voseo">vos</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">second person</a> <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">singular</a> <a href="/wiki/Pronoun" title="Pronoun">pronoun</a>, found in several Latin American varieties, is replaced by <i><a href="/wiki/T%E2%80%93V_distinction#Spanish" title="T–V distinction">tú</a></i>; whereas <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vosotros" title="Vosotros">vosotros</a></i>, the second person plural pronoun, fell out of use and was effectively replaced by <i>ustedes</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_346-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-346">[342]</a></sup> In written form, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_Royal_Academy" title="Spanish Royal Academy">Spanish Royal Academy</a> serves as the primary guideline for spelling, except for words of Amerindian origin that retain their original phonology such as <i><a href="/wiki/Northern_mockingbird" title="Northern mockingbird">cenzontle</a></i> instead of <i>sinzontle</i> and <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico"><i>México</i> not <i>Méjico</i></a>. Words of foreign origin also maintain their original spelling such as "whisky" and "film", as opposed to <i>güisqui</i> and <i>filme</i> as the Royal Academy suggests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_346-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-346">[342]</a></sup> The letter <i>x</i> is distinctly used in Mexican Spanish, where it may be pronounced as <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ks]</span> (as in <i>oxígeno</i> or <i>taxi</i>); as <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ʃ]</span>, particularly in Amerindian words (e.g. <i>mixiote</i>, <i>Xola</i> and <i>uxmal</i>); and as the <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative" title="Voiceless velar fricative">voiceless velar fricative</a> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[<a href="/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative" title="Voiceless velar fricative">x</a>]</span> (such as <i>Texas</i> and <i>Oaxaca</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_346-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-346">[342]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_lenguas_de_M%C3%A9xico_%2B_100_000.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="909" data-file-width="1350" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Mapa_de_lenguas_de_M%C3%A9xico_%2B_100_000.png/220px-Mapa_de_lenguas_de_M%C3%A9xico_%2B_100_000.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Mapa_de_lenguas_de_M%C3%A9xico_%2B_100_000.png/330px-Mapa_de_lenguas_de_M%C3%A9xico_%2B_100_000.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Mapa_de_lenguas_de_M%C3%A9xico_%2B_100_000.png/440px-Mapa_de_lenguas_de_M%C3%A9xico_%2B_100_000.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_lenguas_de_M%C3%A9xico_%2B_100_000.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map for the year 2000 of the indigenous languages of Mexico having more than 100,000 speakers.</div></div></div>
<p>The federal government officially recognizes <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Mexico#Indigenous_languages" title="Languages of Mexico">sixty-eight linguistic groups and 364 varieties of indigenous languages</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[343]</a></sup> It is estimated that around 8.3 million citizens speak these languages,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-348">[344]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a> being the most widely spoken by more than 1.7 million, followed by <a href="/wiki/Yucatec_Maya_language" title="Yucatec Maya language">Yucatec Maya</a> used daily by nearly 850,000 people. <a href="/wiki/Tzeltal_language" title="Tzeltal language">Tzeltal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tzotzil_language" title="Tzotzil language">Tzotzil</a>, two other <a href="/wiki/Mayan_languages" title="Mayan languages">Mayan languages</a>, are spoken by around half a million people each, primarily in the southern state of <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_348-1"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-348">[344]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mixtec_languages" title="Mixtec languages">Mixtec</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_languages" title="Zapotec languages">Zapotec</a>, with an estimated 500,000 native speakers each, are two other prominent language groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_348-2"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-348">[344]</a></sup> Since its creation in March 2003, the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Lenguas_Ind%C3%ADgenas" title="Instituto Nacional de Lenguas Indígenas">National Indigenous Languages Institute</a> has been in charge of promoting and protecting the use of the country's indigenous languages, through the <a href="/wiki/Ley_General_de_Derechos_Ling%C3%BC%C3%ADsticos_de_los_Pueblos_Ind%C3%ADgenas" title="Ley General de Derechos Lingüísticos de los Pueblos Indígenas">General Law of Indigenous Peoples' Linguistic Rights</a>, which recognizes them <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> as "national languages" with status equal to that of Spanish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[345]</a></sup> That notwithstanding, in practice, indigenous peoples often face discrimination and don't have full access to public services such as education and healthcare, or to the justice system, as Spanish is the prevailing language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>Aside from indigenous languages, there are several minority languages spoken in Mexico due to international migration such as <a href="/wiki/Low_German" title="Low German">Low German</a> by the 80,000-strong <a href="/wiki/Mennonites_in_Mexico" title="Mennonites in Mexico">Mennonite population</a>, primarily settled in the northern states, fueled by the tolerance of the federal government towards this community by allowing them to set their own educational system compatible with their customs and traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[347]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chipilo_Venetian_dialect" title="Chipilo Venetian dialect">Chipilo dialect</a>, a variance of the <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">Venetian language</a>, is spoken in the town of <a href="/wiki/Chipilo" title="Chipilo">Chipilo</a>, located in the central state of <a href="/wiki/Puebla" title="Puebla">Puebla</a>, by around 2,500 people, mainly descendants of Venetians that migrated to the area in the late 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[348]</a></sup> Furthermore, <a href="/wiki/English_as_a_second_or_foreign_language" title="English as a second or foreign language">English</a> is the most commonly taught foreign language in Mexico. It is estimated that nearly 24 million, or around a fifth of the population, study the language through public schools, private institutions or self-access channels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[349]</a></sup> However, a high level of English proficiency is limited to only 5% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[350]</a></sup> Moreover, <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> is the second most widely taught foreign language, as every year between 200,000 and 250,000 Mexican students enroll in language courses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[353]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Emigration_and_immigration">Emigration and immigration</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Emigration_from_Mexico" title="Emigration from Mexico">Emigration from Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Mexico" title="Immigration to Mexico">Immigration to Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Border_USA_Mexico.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2475" data-file-width="3600" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Border_USA_Mexico.jpg/220px-Border_USA_Mexico.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Border_USA_Mexico.jpg/330px-Border_USA_Mexico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Border_USA_Mexico.jpg/440px-Border_USA_Mexico.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Border_USA_Mexico.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_barrier" title="Mexico–United States barrier">Mexico–United States barrier</a> between <a href="/wiki/San_Diego" title="San Diego">San Diego</a>'s border patrol offices in <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, USA (left) and <a href="/wiki/Tijuana" title="Tijuana">Tijuana</a>, Mexico (right)</div></div></div>
<p>In the early 1960s, around 600,000 Mexicans lived abroad, which increased sevenfold by the 1990s to 4.4 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-358">[354]</a></sup> At the turn of the 21st century, this figure more than doubled to 9.5 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_358-1"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-358">[354]</a></sup> As of 2017, it is estimated that 12.9 million Mexicans live abroad, primarily in the United States, which concentrates nearly 98% of the expatriate population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_358-2"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-358">[354]</a></sup>
</p><p>The majority of Mexicans have settled in states such as <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a>, particularly around the metropolitan areas of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_metropolitan_area" title="Los Angeles metropolitan area">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicago_metropolitan_area" title="Chicago metropolitan area">Chicago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greater_Houston" title="Greater Houston">Houston</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dallas%E2%80%93Fort_Worth_metroplex" title="Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex">Dallas–Fort Worth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[355]</a></sup> As a result of these major migration flows in recent decades, around 36 million U.S. residents, or 11.2% of the country's population, identified as being of full or partial Mexican ancestry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[356]</a></sup>
</p><p>The remaining 2% of expatriates have settled in <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> (86,000), primarily in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Ontario" title="Ontario">Ontario</a> and <a href="/wiki/Quebec" title="Quebec">Quebec</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[357]</a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> (49,000) and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> (18,000), both European destinations represent almost two-thirds of the Mexican population living in the continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_358-3"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-358">[354]</a></sup> As for Latin America, it is estimated that 69,000 Mexicans live in the region, <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> (18,000) being the top destination for expatriates, followed by <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> (10,000) and <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a> (5,000).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_358-4"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-358">[354]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, it is estimated that 1.2 million foreigners have settled in Mexico,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN2017_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-362">[358]</a></sup> up from nearly 1 million in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[359]</a></sup> The vast majority of migrants come from the United States (900,000), making Mexico the top destination for <a href="/wiki/American_immigration_to_Mexico" title="American immigration to Mexico">U.S. citizens abroad</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[360]</a></sup> The second largest group comes from neighboring <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> (54,500), followed by <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> (27,600).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN2017_362-1"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-362">[358]</a></sup> Other major sources of migration are fellow Latin American countries, which include <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> (20,600), <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> (19,200) and <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a> (18,100).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN2017_362-2"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-362">[358]</a></sup> Historically, the <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_Mexicans" title="Lebanese Mexicans">Lebanese diaspora</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mennonites_in_Mexico" title="Mennonites in Mexico">German-born Mennonite migration</a> have left a notorious impact in the country's culture, particularly in its cuisine and traditional music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Garcia_2005_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-Garcia_2005-365">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[362]</a></sup> At the turn of the 21st century, several trends have increased the number of foreigners residing in the country such as the <a href="/wiki/2008%E2%80%932014_Spanish_financial_crisis" title="2008–2014 Spanish financial crisis">2008–2014 Spanish financial crisis</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[363]</a></sup> increasing gang-related violence in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Triangle_of_Central_America" title="Northern Triangle of Central America">Northern Triangle of Central America</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[364]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Crisis_in_Venezuela" title="Crisis in Venezuela">ongoing political and economic crisis in Venezuela</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[366]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Mexico" title="Automotive industry in Mexico">automotive industry boom</a> led by Japanese and South Korean investment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[368]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urban_areas">Urban areas</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Mexico" title="Metropolitan areas of Mexico">Metropolitan areas of Mexico</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Mexico" title="List of cities in Mexico">List of cities in Mexico</a></div>
<div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Mexico" title="Religion in Mexico">Religion in Mexico</a></div>
