<div class="thumbcaption">
<p>Religion in Mexico (2020 census)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020-census_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-2020-census-374">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statista_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-statista-375">[371]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Purple; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Mexico" title="Catholic Church in Mexico">Roman Catholic</a> (72.1%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Blue; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Mexico" title="Protestantism in Mexico">Evangelist (unspecified)</a> (2.5%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:SkyBlue; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witness" title="Jehovah's Witness">Jehovah's Witness</a> (1.7%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Red; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pentecostal" title="Pentecostal">Pentecostal</a> <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">evangelist</a> (1.3%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">Irreligion</a> (15.3%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:black; color:white;"> </span> Unspecified (Do not answer/Do not known) (2.7%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:DarkGreen; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Baptists" title="Baptists">Baptists</a> (0.4%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Green; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Adventism" title="Adventism">Adventists</a> (0.4%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Yellow; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mormonism_in_Mexico" title="Mormonism in Mexico">Mormons</a> (0.2%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:DarkGray; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Mexico" title="Irreligion in Mexico">Atheist</a> (0.9%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Gray; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agnostics" title="Agnostics">Agnostics</a> (0.1%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Orange; color:black;"> </span> Other (1.4%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Although the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_1857" title="Constitution of 1857">Constitutions of 1857</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_1917" title="Constitution of 1917">1917</a> put limits on the role of the Roman Catholic Church in Mexico, Roman Catholicism remains the country's dominant religious affiliation.  The 2020 census by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía</a> (National Institute of Statistics and Geography) gives <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Mexico" title="Roman Catholicism in Mexico">Roman Catholicism</a> as the main religion, with 77.7% (97,864,218) of the population, while 11.2% (14,095,307) belong to Protestant/Evangelical Christian denominations—including Other <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> (6,778,435), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelicals" title="Evangelicals">Evangelicals</a> (2,387,133), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pentecostals" title="Pentecostals">Pentecostals</a> (1,179,415), <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> (1,530,909), <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a> (791,109), and members of <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a> (337,998)—; 8.1% (9,488,671) declared having <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Mexico" title="Irreligion in Mexico">no religion</a>; .4% (491,814) were unspecified.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-9"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religion2020_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-religion2020-376">[372]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 97,864,218<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-10"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup> Catholics of Mexico constitute in absolute terms the second largest Catholic community in the world, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>'s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[373]</a></sup> 47% percent of them attend church services weekly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[374]</a></sup> The feast day of <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Our Lady of Guadalupe">Our Lady of Guadalupe</a>, the patron saint of Mexico, is celebrated on 12 December and is regarded by many Mexicans as the most important religious holiday of their country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[375]</a></sup> The denominations <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostal</a> also have an important presence, especially in the cities of the border and in the indigenous communities. As of 2010, Pentecostal churches together have more than 1.3 million adherents, which in net numbers place them as the second Christian creed in Mexico. The situation changes when the different Pentecostal denominations are considered as separate entities. Migratory phenomena have led to the spread of different aspects of Christianity, including branches <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cristianismosorientales_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-cristianismosorientales-380">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>In certain regions, the profession of a creed other than the Catholic is seen as a threat to community unity. It is argued that the Catholic religion is part of the ethnic identity, and that the Protestants are not willing to participate in the traditional customs and practices (the <a href="/wiki/Tequio" title="Tequio">tequio</a> or community work, participation in the festivities and similar issues). The refusal of the Protestants is because their religious beliefs do not allow them to participate in the cult of images. In extreme cases, tension between Catholics and Protestants has led to the expulsion or even murder of Protestants in several villages. The best known cases are those of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San_Juan_Chamula" title="San Juan Chamula">San Juan Chamula</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[378]</a></sup> in Chiapas, and San Nicolás, in <a href="/wiki/Ixmiquilpan" title="Ixmiquilpan">Ixmiquilpan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[379]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hidalgo_(state)" title="Hidalgo (state)">Hidalgo</a>. A similar argument was presented by a committee of anthropologists to request the government of the Republic to expel the <a href="/wiki/SIL_International" title="SIL International">Summer Linguistic Institute</a> (SIL), in the year 1979, which was accused of promoting the division of indigenous peoples by translating the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> into vernacular languages and evangelizing in a Protestant creed that threatened the integrity of popular cultures. The Mexican government paid attention to the call of the anthropologists and canceled the agreement that had held with the SIL.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WP_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-WP-384">[380]</a></sup>
</p><p>The presence of <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Mexico" title="History of the Jews in Mexico">Jews in Mexico</a> dates back to 1521, when Hernán Cortés conquered the Aztecs, accompanied by several <a href="/wiki/Converso" title="Converso">Conversos</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[381]</a></sup> According to the 2020 census, there are 58,876 Jews in Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-11"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Mexico" title="Islam in Mexico">Islam in Mexico</a> (with 7,982 members) is practiced mostly by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_Mexican" title="Arab Mexican">Arab Mexicans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-12"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup> In the 2010 census 36,764 Mexicans reported belonging to a spiritualist religion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_Census_1-13"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-1">[1]</a></sup> a category which includes a tiny <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Mexico" title="Buddhism in Mexico">Buddhist</a> population.
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Jacobo_Grinberg" title="Jacobo Grinberg">Jacobo Grinberg</a> (in texts edited by the <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a>), the survival of magic-religious rituals of the old <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">indigenous</a> groups is remarkable, not only in the current indigenous population but also in the <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">mestizo</a> and <a href="/wiki/White_people" title="White people">white</a> population that make up the Mexican rural and urban society. There is often a <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretism</a> between <a href="/wiki/Shamanism" title="Shamanism">shamanism</a> and Catholic traditions. Another religion of popular syncretism in Mexico (especially in recent years) is the <a href="/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa" title="Santería">Santería</a>. This is mainly due to the large number of Cubans who settled in the territory after the <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolution" title="Cuban Revolution">Cuban Revolution</a> (mainly in states such as <a href="/wiki/Veracruz" title="Veracruz">Veracruz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Yucatán">Yucatán</a>). Even though Mexico was also a recipient of black slaves from <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> in the 16th century, the apogee of these cults is relatively new.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[382]</a></sup> In general, popular religiosity is viewed with bad eyes by institutionally structured religions. One of the most exemplary cases of popular religiosity is the cult of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Muerte" title="Santa Muerte">Holy Dead</a> (Santa Muerte). The Catholic hierarchy insists on describing it as a satanic cult. However, most of the people who profess this cult declare themselves to be Catholic believers, and consider that there is no contradiction between the tributes they offer to the <a href="/wiki/Christ_Child" title="Christ Child">Christ Child</a> and the adoration of God. Other examples are the representations of the <a href="/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross" title="Stations of the Cross">Passion of Christ</a> and the celebration of <a href="/wiki/Day_of_the_Dead" title="Day of the Dead">Day of the Dead</a>, which take place within the framework of the Catholic Christian imaginary, but under a very particular reinterpretation of its protagonists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[383]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Mexico" title="Healthcare in Mexico">Healthcare in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud,_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.,_M%C3%A9xico,_2013-10-13,_DD_12.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2174" data-file-width="3398" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2013-10-13%2C_DD_12.jpg/220px-Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2013-10-13%2C_DD_12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2013-10-13%2C_DD_12.jpg/330px-Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2013-10-13%2C_DD_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2013-10-13%2C_DD_12.jpg/440px-Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2013-10-13%2C_DD_12.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud,_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.,_M%C3%A9xico,_2013-10-13,_DD_12.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Health_(Mexico)" title="Secretariat of Health (Mexico)">Secretary of Health</a>, Mexico City, Mexico.</div></div></div>
<p>In the 1930s, Mexico made a commitment to rural health care, mandating that mostly urban medical students receive training in it and to make them agents of the state to assess marginal areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[384]</a></sup> Since the early 1990s, Mexico entered a transitional stage in the health of its population and some indicators such as mortality patterns are identical to those found in highly developed countries like Germany or Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[385]</a></sup> Mexico's medical infrastructure is highly rated for the most part and is usually excellent in major cities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Health_Care_in_Mexico_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-Health_Care_in_Mexico-390">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[387]</a></sup> but rural communities still lack equipment for advanced medical procedures, forcing patients in those locations to travel to the closest urban areas to get specialized medical care.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brit-mex_206-2"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-206">[203]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_determinants_of_health_in_Mexico" title="Social determinants of health in Mexico">Social determinants of health</a> can be used to evaluate the state of health in Mexico.
</p><p>State-funded institutions such as <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Social_Security_Institute" title="Mexican Social Security Institute">Mexican Social Security Institute</a> (IMSS) and the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Social_Security_and_Services_for_State_Workers" title="Institute for Social Security and Services for State Workers">Institute for Social Security and Services for State Workers</a> (ISSSTE) play a major role in health and social security. Private health services are also very important and account for 13% of all medical units in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[388]</a></sup> Medical training is done mostly at public universities with much specializations done in vocational or internship settings. Some public universities in Mexico, such as the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Guadalajara" title="University of Guadalajara">University of Guadalajara</a>, have signed agreements with the U.S. to receive and train American students in Medicine. Health care costs in private institutions and prescription drugs in Mexico are on average lower than that of its North American economic partners.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Health_Care_in_Mexico_390-1"><a href="#cite_note-Health_Care_in_Mexico-390">[386]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Mexico" title="Education in Mexico">Education in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:-_panoramio_(2288).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1635" data-file-width="2721" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/-_panoramio_%282288%29.jpg/220px--_panoramio_%282288%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/-_panoramio_%282288%29.jpg/330px--_panoramio_%282288%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/-_panoramio_%282288%29.jpg/440px--_panoramio_%282288%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:-_panoramio_(2288).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Central_Library_(UNAM)" title="Central Library (UNAM)">Central Library</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 2004, the literacy rate was at 97%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[389]</a></sup> for youth under the age of 14, and 91% for people over 15,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[390]</a></sup> placing Mexico at 24th place in the world according to <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[391]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nowadays, Mexico's literacy rate is high, at 94.86% in 2018, up from 82.99% in 1980,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[392]</a></sup> with the literacy rates of males and females being relatively equal. The <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a> ranks 103rd in the <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a>, making it the best university in Mexico. After it comes the <a href="/wiki/Monterrey_Institute_of_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education">Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education</a> as the best private school in Mexico and 158th worldwide in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[393]</a></sup>
</p><p>Private business schools also stand out in international rankings. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IPADE" title="IPADE">IPADE</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EGADE" title="EGADE">EGADE</a>, the business schools of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universidad_Panamericana" title="Universidad Panamericana">Universidad Panamericana</a> and of <a href="/wiki/Monterrey_Institute_of_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education">Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education</a> respectively, were ranked in the top 10 in a survey conducted by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> among recruiters outside the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[394]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Mexico" title="Culture of Mexico">Culture of Mexico</a></div>
<p>Mexican culture reflects the complexity of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico" title="History of Mexico">country's history</a> through the blending of indigenous cultures and the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Spain" title="Culture of Spain">culture of Spain</a> during Spain's 300-year colonial rule of Mexico. The Porfirian era (<i>el <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">Porfiriato</a></i>) (1876-1911), was marked by economic progress and peace. After four decades of civil unrest and war, Mexico saw the development of philosophy and the arts, promoted by President Porfirio Díaz himself. Since that time, as accentuated during the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a>, cultural identity has had its foundation in the <i>mestizaje</i>, of which the indigenous (i.e. Amerindian) element is the core. In light of the various ethnicities that formed the Mexican people, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Vasconcelos" title="José Vasconcelos">José Vasconcelos</a> in <i>La Raza Cósmica</i> (The Cosmic Race) (1925) defined Mexico to be the melting pot of all races (thus extending the definition of the <i>mestizo</i>) not only biologically but culturally as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vasconcelos160_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-vasconcelos160-399">[395]</a></sup> Other Mexican intellectuals grappled with the idea of <i>Lo Mexicano</i>, which seeks "to discover the national ethos of Mexican culture."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[396]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_laureate" title="Nobel laureate">Nobel laureate</a> <a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a> explores the notion of a Mexican national character in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Labyrinth_of_Solitude" title="The Labyrinth of Solitude">The Labyrinth of Solitude</a></i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_art" title="Mexican art">Mexican art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Diego_Rivera_and_Frida_Kahlo.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="324" data-file-width="307" decoding="async" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Diego_Rivera_and_Frida_Kahlo.jpg/170px-Diego_Rivera_and_Frida_Kahlo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Diego_Rivera_and_Frida_Kahlo.jpg/255px-Diego_Rivera_and_Frida_Kahlo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e1/Diego_Rivera_and_Frida_Kahlo.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Diego_Rivera_and_Frida_Kahlo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">Diego Rivera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Frida_Kahlo" title="Frida Kahlo">Frida Kahlo</a>, two of the most famous mexican artists</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">Painting</a> is one of the oldest arts in Mexico. Cave painting in Mexican territory is about 7500 years old and has been found in the caves of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baja_California_Peninsula" title="Baja California Peninsula">Baja California Peninsula</a>. Pre-Columbian Mexico is present in buildings and caves, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aztec_codices" title="Aztec codices">Aztec codices</a>, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ceramics" title="Ceramics">ceramics</a>, in garments, etc.; examples of this are the <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a> mural paintings of <a href="/wiki/Bonampak" title="Bonampak">Bonampak</a>, or those of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teotihuac%C3%A1n" title="Teotihuacán">Teotihuacán</a>, those of <a href="/wiki/Cacaxtla" title="Cacaxtla">Cacaxtla</a> and those of <a href="/wiki/Monte_Alb%C3%A1n" title="Monte Albán">Monte Albán</a>.
Mural painting with Christian religious themes had an important flowering during the 16th century, early colonial era in newly constructed churches and monasteries. Examples can be found in <a href="/wiki/Acolman" title="Acolman">Acolman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Actopan,_Hidalgo" title="Actopan, Hidalgo">Actopan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Huejotzingo" title="Huejotzingo">Huejotzingo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tecamachalco,_Puebla" title="Tecamachalco, Puebla">Tecamachalco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zinacantepec" title="Zinacantepec">Zinacantepec</a>.
</p><p>As with most art during the early modern era in the West, colonial-era Mexican art was religious during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. Starting in the late seventeenth century, and, most prominently in the eighteenth century, secular portraits and images of racial types, so-called <a href="/wiki/Casta" title="Casta">casta painting</a> appeared.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[397]</a></sup>  Important painters of the late colonial period were <a href="/wiki/Juan_Correa" title="Juan Correa">Juan Correa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crist%C3%B3bal_de_Villalpando" title="Cristóbal de Villalpando">Cristóbal de Villalpando</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Cabrera_(painter)" title="Miguel Cabrera (painter)">Miguel Cabrera</a>. In early post-independence Mexico, Nineteenth-century painting had a marked romantic influence; landscapes and portraits were the greatest expressions of this era. <a href="/wiki/Hermenegildo_Bustos" title="Hermenegildo Bustos">Hermenegildo Bustos</a> is one of the most appreciated painters of the <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">historiography</a> of Mexican art. Other painters include <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santiago_Rebull" title="es:Santiago Rebull">Santiago Rebull</a>, <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Parra" title="Félix Parra">Félix Parra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Landesio" title="Eugenio Landesio">Eugenio Landesio</a>, and his noted pupil, the landscape artist <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Velasco_G%C3%B3mez" title="José María Velasco Gómez">José María Velasco</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[398]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 20th century has achieved world renown with painters such as <a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">Diego Rivera</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">David Alfaro Siqueiros</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Clemente_Orozco" title="José Clemente Orozco">José Clemente Orozco</a>, the so-called "Big Three" of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_muralism" title="Mexican muralism">Mexican muralism</a>. They were commissioned by the Mexican government to paint large-scale historical murals on the walls of public buildings, such as the , which helped shape popular perceptions of the Mexican Revolution and Mexican cultural identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[399]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Frida_Kahlo" title="Frida Kahlo">Frida Kahlo</a>'s largely personal portraiture has gained enormous popularity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[400]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Mexico" title="Architecture of Mexico">Architecture of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes,_Mexico_City,_MX.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3157" data-file-width="4735" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes%2C_Mexico_City%2C_MX.jpg/220px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes%2C_Mexico_City%2C_MX.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes%2C_Mexico_City%2C_MX.jpg/330px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes%2C_Mexico_City%2C_MX.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes%2C_Mexico_City%2C_MX.jpg/440px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes%2C_Mexico_City%2C_MX.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes,_Mexico_City,_MX.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a> (Palace of Fine Arts), with murals, other artwork, and a major performance space</div></div></div>
<p>In the 19th century the neoclassical movement arose as a response to the objectives of the republican nation, one of its examples are the <a href="/wiki/Hospicio_Caba%C3%B1as" title="Hospicio Cabañas">Hospicio Cabañas</a> where the strict plastic of the classical orders are represented in their architectural elements, new religious buildings also arise, civilian and military that demonstrate the presence of neoclassicism. Romanticists from a past seen through archeology show images of medieval Europe, Islamic and pre-Columbian Mexico in the form of architectural elements in the construction of international exhibition pavilions looking for an identity typical of the national culture. The <i>art nouveau</i>, and the <i>art deco</i> were styles introduced into the design of the <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a> to mark the identity of the Mexican nation with Greek-Roman and pre-Columbian symbols.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The emergence of the new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_architecture" title="Mexican architecture">Mexican architecture</a> was born as a formal order of the policies of a nationalist state that sought modernity and the differentiation of other nations. The development of a Mexican modernist architecture was perhaps mostly fully manifested in the mid-1950s construction of the <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Universitaria,_Mexico_City" title="Ciudad Universitaria, Mexico City">Ciudad Universitaria, Mexico City</a>, the main campus of the <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a>. Designed by the most prestigious architects of the era, including <a href="/wiki/Mario_Pani" title="Mario Pani">Mario Pani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Peschard" title="Eugenio Peschard">Eugenio Peschard</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Enrique_del_Moral" title="Enrique del Moral">Enrique del Moral</a>, the buildings feature murals by artists <a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">Diego Rivera</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">David Alfaro Siqueiros</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Ch%C3%A1vez_Morado" title="José Chávez Morado">José Chávez Morado</a>. It has since been recognized as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[401]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Juan_O%27Gorman" title="Juan O'Gorman">Juan O'Gorman</a> was one of the first environmental architects in Mexico, developing the "organic" theory, trying to integrate the building with the landscape within the same approaches of <a href="/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright" title="Frank Lloyd Wright">Frank Lloyd Wright</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[402]</a></sup> In the search for a new architecture that does not resemble the styles of the past, it achieves a joint manifestation with the mural painting and the <a href="/wiki/Landscaping" title="Landscaping">landscaping</a>. <a href="/wiki/Luis_Barrag%C3%A1n" title="Luis Barragán">Luis Barragán</a> combined the shape of the space with forms of rural vernacular architecture of Mexico and Mediterranean countries (Spain-Morocco), integrating color that handles light and shade in different tones and opens a look at the international <a href="/wiki/Minimalism" title="Minimalism">minimalism</a>. He won the 1980 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pritzker_Prize" title="Pritzker Prize">Pritzker Prize</a>, the highest award in architecture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eighty_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-eighty-407">[403]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_cuisine" title="Mexican cuisine">Mexican cuisine</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_wine" title="Mexican wine">Mexican wine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="4320" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/220px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/330px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/440px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mole_sauce" title="Mole sauce">Mole sauce</a></i>, which has dozens of varieties across the Republic, is seen as a symbol of <i>Mexicanidad</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mole_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mole-408">[404]</a></sup> and is considered Mexico's national dish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mole_408-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mole-408">[404]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The origin of the current Mexican cuisine was established during the Spanish colonial era, a mixture of the foods of <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> with native indigenous ingredients.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[405]</a></sup> Foods indigenous to Mexico include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corn" title="Corn">corn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capsicum" title="Capsicum">pepper vegetables</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calabaza" title="Calabaza">calabazas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Avocado" title="Avocado">avocados</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sweet_potato" title="Sweet potato">sweet potato</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey_as_food" title="Turkey as food">turkey</a>, many <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a>, and other fruits and spices. Similarly, some cooking techniques used today are inherited from pre-Columbian peoples, such as the <a href="/wiki/Nixtamalization" title="Nixtamalization">nixtamalization</a> of corn, the cooking of food in ovens at ground level, grinding in <a href="/wiki/Molcajete" title="Molcajete">molcajete</a> and <a href="/wiki/Metate" title="Metate">metate</a>. With the Spaniards came the pork, beef and chicken meats; <a href="/wiki/Piper_(plant)" title="Piper (plant)">peppercorn</a>, sugar, milk and all its derivatives, wheat and rice, citrus fruits and another constellation of ingredients that are part of the daily diet of Mexicans.
</p><p>From this meeting of millennia old two culinary traditions, were born <a href="/wiki/Pozole" title="Pozole">pozole</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mole_sauce" title="Mole sauce">mole sauce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbacoa" title="Barbacoa">barbacoa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tamale" title="Tamale">tamale</a> is in its current forms, the <a href="/wiki/Chocolate" title="Chocolate">chocolate</a>, a large range of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_breads" title="Mexican breads">breads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taco" title="Taco">tacos</a>, and the broad repertoire of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_street_food" title="Mexican street food">Mexican street foods</a>. Beverages such as <a href="/wiki/Atole" title="Atole">atole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Champurrado" title="Champurrado">champurrado</a>, milk chocolate and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aguas_frescas" title="Aguas frescas">aguas frescas</a> were born; desserts such as <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Acitr%C3%B3n&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Acitrón (page does not exist)">acitrón</a> and the full range of crystallized sweets, <a href="/wiki/Rompope" title="Rompope">rompope</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cajeta" title="Cajeta">cajeta</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jericaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jericaya (page does not exist)">jericaya</a> and the wide repertoire of delights created in the convents of nuns in all parts of the country.
</p><p>In 2005, Mexico presented the candidature of its gastronomy for <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> of UNESCO, the first time a country had presented its gastronomic tradition for this purpose.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[406]</a></sup> The result was negative, because the committee did not place the proper emphasis on the importance of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corn" title="Corn">corn</a> in Mexican cuisine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[407]</a></sup> On 16 November 2010 Mexican gastronomy was recognized as <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage" title="Intangible cultural heritage">Intangible cultural heritage</a> by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GastronomiaPatrimonio_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-GastronomiaPatrimonio-412">[408]</a></sup> In addition, <a href="/wiki/Daniela_Soto-Innes" title="Daniela Soto-Innes">Daniela Soto-Innes</a> was named the best female chef in the world by <i>The World's Best 50 Restaurants</i> in April 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[409]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_literature" title="Mexican literature">Mexican literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Octavio_Paz_-_1988_Malm%C3%B6.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="888" data-file-width="644" decoding="async" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Octavio_Paz_-_1988_Malm%C3%B6.jpg/170px-Octavio_Paz_-_1988_Malm%C3%B6.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Octavio_Paz_-_1988_Malm%C3%B6.jpg/255px-Octavio_Paz_-_1988_Malm%C3%B6.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Octavio_Paz_-_1988_Malm%C3%B6.jpg/340px-Octavio_Paz_-_1988_Malm%C3%B6.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Octavio_Paz_-_1988_Malm%C3%B6.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a>, the only mexican awarded with the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a></div></div></div>
<p>Mexican literature has its antecedents in the literature of the indigenous settlements of Mesoamerica. Poetry had a rich cultural tradition in pre-Columbian Mexico, being divided into two broad categories—secular and religious. Aztec poetry was sung, chanted, or spoken, often to the accompaniment of a drum or a harp. While Tenochtitlan was the political capital, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texcoco_(altepetl)" title="Texcoco (altepetl)">Texcoco</a> was the cultural center; the Texcocan language was considered the most melodious and refined. The best well-known pre-Columbian poet is <a href="/wiki/Nezahualcoyotl_(tlatoani)" title="Nezahualcoyotl (tlatoani)">Nezahualcoyotl</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are historical chronicles of the conquest of Mexico by participants, and, later, by historians. <a href="/wiki/Bernal_D%C3%ADaz_del_Castillo" title="Bernal Díaz del Castillo">Bernal Díaz del Castillo's</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Historia_verdadera_de_la_conquista_de_la_Nueva_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Historia verdadera de la conquista de la Nueva España">True History of the Conquest of the New Spain</a></i> is still widely read today. Spanish-born poet <a href="/wiki/Bernardo_de_Balbuena" title="Bernardo de Balbuena">Bernardo de Balbuena</a> extolled the virtues of Mexico in <i>Grandeza mexicana</i> (Mexican grandeur) (1604). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baroque_literature" title="Baroque literature">Baroque literature</a> flourished in the 17th century; the most notable writers of this period were <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ruiz_de_Alarc%C3%B3n" title="Juan Ruiz de Alarcón">Juan Ruiz de Alarcón</a> and <a href="/wiki/Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz" title="Juana Inés de la Cruz">Juana Inés de la Cruz</a>. Sor Juana was famous in her own time, called the "Ten Muse."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-415">[411]</a></sup>
</p><p>The late colonial-era novel by <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Joaqu%C3%ADn_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Lizardi" title="José Joaquín Fernández de Lizardi">José Joaquín Fernández de Lizardi</a>, whose <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mangy_Parrot" title="The Mangy Parrot">The Mangy Parrot</a></i> ("El Periquillo Sarniento"), is said to be the first Latin American novel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_415-1"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-415">[411]</a></sup> Nineteenth-century liberal of Nahua origin <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_Manuel_Altamirano" title="Ignacio Manuel Altamirano">Ignacio Manuel Altamirano</a> is an important writer of the era, along with <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Riva_Palacio" title="Vicente Riva Palacio">Vicente Riva Palacio</a>, the grandson of Mexican hero of independence <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a>, who authored a series of historical novels as well as poetry.  In the modern era, the novel of the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a> by <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Azuela" title="Mariano Azuela">Mariano Azuela</a> (<i>Los de abajo</i>, translated to English as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Underdogs_(novel)" title="The Underdogs (novel)">The Underdogs</a></i>) is noteworthy. Poet and Nobel Laureate <a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a>, novelist <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Fuentes" title="Carlos Fuentes">Carlos Fuentes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Reyes" title="Alfonso Reyes">Alfonso Reyes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renato_Leduc" title="Renato Leduc">Renato Leduc</a>, essayist <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Monsiv%C3%A1is" title="Carlos Monsiváis">Carlos Monsiváis</a>, journalist and public intellectual <a href="/wiki/Elena_Poniatowska" title="Elena Poniatowska">Elena Poniatowska</a>,  and <a href="/wiki/Juan_Rulfo" title="Juan Rulfo">Juan Rulfo</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Pedro_P%C3%A1ramo" title="Pedro Páramo">Pedro Páramo</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Luis_Guzm%C3%A1n" title="Martín Luis Guzmán">Martín Luis Guzmán</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nellie_Campobello" title="Nellie Campobello">Nellie Campobello</a>, (<i><a href="/wiki/Cartucho" title="Cartucho">Cartucho</a></i>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Mexico" title="Cinema of Mexico">Cinema of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n,_President_jury_Venezia_72_(25805089406)_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="513" data-file-width="403" decoding="async" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n%2C_President_jury_Venezia_72_%2825805089406%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n%2C_President_jury_Venezia_72_%2825805089406%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n%2C_President_jury_Venezia_72_%2825805089406%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n%2C_President_jury_Venezia_72_%2825805089406%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n%2C_President_jury_Venezia_72_%2825805089406%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n%2C_President_jury_Venezia_72_%2825805089406%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n,_President_jury_Venezia_72_(25805089406)_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n" title="Alfonso Cuarón">Alfonso Cuarón</a>, the first mexican filmmaker to win the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director" title="Academy Award for Best Director">Academy Award for Best Director</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Mexico" title="Cinema of Mexico">Mexican films</a> from the <i><a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Mexican_cinema" title="Golden Age of Mexican cinema">Golden Age</a></i> in the 1940s and 1950s are the greatest examples of Latin American cinema, with a huge industry comparable to the Hollywood of those years. Mexican films were exported and exhibited in all of Latin America and Europe. <i><a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_Candelaria" title="María Candelaria">María Candelaria</a></i> (1943) by <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Fern%C3%A1ndez" title="Emilio Fernández">Emilio Fernández</a>, was one of the first films awarded a <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> in 1946, the first time the event was held after World War II. The famous Spanish-born director <a href="/wiki/Luis_Bu%C3%B1uel" title="Luis Buñuel">Luis Buñuel</a> realized in Mexico between 1947 and 1965 some of his masterpieces like <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Olvidados" title="Los Olvidados">Los Olvidados</a></i> (1949) and <i><a href="/wiki/Viridiana" title="Viridiana">Viridiana</a></i> (1961). Famous actors and actresses from this period include <a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_F%C3%A9lix" title="María Félix">María Félix</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Infante" title="Pedro Infante">Pedro Infante</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo" title="Dolores del Río">Dolores del Río</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Negrete" title="Jorge Negrete">Jorge Negrete</a> and the comedian <a href="/wiki/Cantinflas" title="Cantinflas">Cantinflas</a>.
</p><p>More recently, films such as <i><a href="/wiki/Like_Water_for_Chocolate_(film)" title="Like Water for Chocolate (film)">Como agua para chocolate</a></i> (1992), <i><a href="/wiki/Sexo,_pudor_y_l%C3%A1grimas" title="Sexo, pudor y lágrimas">Sex, Shame, and Tears</a></i> (1999), <i><a href="/wiki/Y_tu_mam%C3%A1_tambi%C3%A9n" title="Y tu mamá también">Y tu mamá también</a></i> (2001), and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_crimen_del_Padre_Amaro" title="El crimen del Padre Amaro">The Crime of Father Amaro</a></i> (2002) have been successful in creating universal stories about contemporary subjects, and were internationally recognized. Mexican directors <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Gonz%C3%A1lez_I%C3%B1%C3%A1rritu" title="Alejandro González Iñárritu">Alejandro González Iñárritu</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Amores_perros" title="Amores perros">Amores perros</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Babel_(film)" title="Babel (film)">Babel</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Birdman_(film)" title="Birdman (film)">Birdman</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Revenant_(2015_film)" title="The Revenant (2015 film)">The Revenant</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n" title="Alfonso Cuarón">Alfonso Cuarón</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/A_Little_Princess_(1995_film)" title="A Little Princess (1995 film)">A Little Princess</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Gravity_(2013_film)" title="Gravity (2013 film)">Gravity</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Roma_(2018_film)" title="Roma (2018 film)">Roma</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_del_Toro" title="Guillermo del Toro">Guillermo del Toro</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Hellboy_(2004_film)" title="Hellboy (2004 film)">Hellboy</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Pan%27s_Labyrinth" title="Pan's Labyrinth">Pan's Labyrinth</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Crimson_Peak" title="Crimson Peak">Crimson Peak</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Shape_of_Water" title="The Shape of Water">The Shape of Water</a></i>), screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Arriaga" title="Guillermo Arriaga">Guillermo Arriaga</a> and photographer <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Lubezki" title="Emmanuel Lubezki">Emmanuel Lubezki</a> are some of the most known present-day film makers.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">Music and dance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Mexico" title="Music of Mexico">Music of Mexico</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_dance_of_Mexico" title="Folk dance of Mexico">Folk dance of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Chavez.jpg"><img alt="A black and white portrait of a middle aged man wearing a dark suit, glasses and looking down." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3664" data-file-width="2868" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Carlos_Chavez.jpg/170px-Carlos_Chavez.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Carlos_Chavez.jpg/255px-Carlos_Chavez.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Carlos_Chavez.jpg/340px-Carlos_Chavez.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Chavez.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mexican composer <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Ch%C3%A1vez" title="Carlos Chávez">Carlos Chávez</a></div></div></div>
<p>Mexico has a long tradition of music from the prehispanic era to the present.Much of the music from the colonial era was composed for religious purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[413]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the traditions of European opera and especially <a href="/wiki/Italian_opera" title="Italian opera">Italian opera</a> had initially dominated the Mexican music conservatories and strongly influenced native opera composers (in both style and subject matter), elements of Mexican nationalism had already appeared by the latter part of the 19th century with operas such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aniceto_Ortega_del_Villar" title="Aniceto Ortega del Villar">Aniceto Ortega del Villar</a>'s 1871 <i><a href="/wiki/Guatimotzin" title="Guatimotzin">Guatimotzin</a></i>, a romanticized account of the defense of Mexico by its last <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aztec" title="Aztec">Aztec</a> ruler, <a href="/wiki/Cuauht%C3%A9moc" title="Cuauhtémoc">Cuauhtémoc</a>. The most well-known Mexican composer of the twentieth century is <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Ch%C3%A1vez" title="Carlos Chávez">Carlos Chávez</a> (1899-1978), who composed six symphonies with indigenous themes, and rejuvenated Mexican music, founding the Orquesta Sinfónica Nacional.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[414]</a></sup>
</p><p>Traditional Mexican music includes <a href="/wiki/Mariachi" title="Mariachi">mariachi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banda_music" title="Banda music">banda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norte%C3%B1o_(music)" title="Norteño (music)">norteño</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ranchera" title="Ranchera">ranchera</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Corrido" title="Corrido">corridos</a>. Corridos were particularly popular during the Mexican Revolution (1910–20) and in the present era include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Narcocorridos" title="Narcocorridos">narcocorridos</a>. The embrace of rock and roll by young Mexicans in the 1960s and 1970s brought Mexico into the transnational, counterculture movement of the era. In Mexico, the native rock culture merged into the larger countercultural and political movement of the late 1960s, culminating in the 1968 protests and redirected into counterculture rebellion, <i><a href="/wiki/La_Onda" title="La Onda">La Onda</a></i> (the wave).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[415]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p>On an everyday basis most Mexicans listen to contemporary music such as <a href="/wiki/Mexican_pop_music" title="Mexican pop music">pop</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rock_music_in_Mexico" title="Rock music in Mexico">rock</a>, and others in both English and Spanish. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_dance_of_Mexico" title="Folk dance of Mexico">Folk dance of Mexico</a> along with its music is both deeply regional and traditional.Founded in 1952, the <a href="/wiki/Ballet_Folkl%C3%B3rico_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Ballet Folklórico de México">Ballet Folklórico de México</a> performs music and dance of the prehispanic period through the Mexican Revolution in regional attire in the <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[417]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_television" title="Mexican television">Mexican television</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Mexico" title="List of newspapers in Mexico">List of newspapers in Mexico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_magazines" title="List of Mexican magazines">List of Mexican magazines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TELEVISA_CHAPULTEPEC.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="854" data-file-width="1205" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/TELEVISA_CHAPULTEPEC.jpg/220px-TELEVISA_CHAPULTEPEC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/TELEVISA_CHAPULTEPEC.jpg/330px-TELEVISA_CHAPULTEPEC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/TELEVISA_CHAPULTEPEC.jpg/440px-TELEVISA_CHAPULTEPEC.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TELEVISA_CHAPULTEPEC.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Televisa" title="Televisa">Televisa</a> headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a></div></div></div>
<p>There was a major reform of the telecommunications industry in 2013, with the creation of new broadcast television channels. There had been a longstanding limitation on the number of networks, with <a href="/wiki/Televisa" title="Televisa">Televisa</a>, with a virtual monopoly; <a href="/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imagen_Television" title="Imagen Television">Imagen Television</a>. New technology has allowed the entry of foreign satellite and cable companies. Mexico became the first Latin American country to transition from analog to all digital transmissions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[418]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Telenovela" title="Telenovela">Telenovelas</a></i>, or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soap_operas" title="Soap operas">soap operas</a> are very traditional in Mexico and are translated to many languages and seen all over the world. Mexico was a pioneer in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edutainment" title="Edutainment">edutainment</a>, with TV producer <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Sabido" title="Miguel Sabido">Miguel Sabido</a> creating in 1970s "soap operas for social change". The "Sabido  method" has been adopted in many other countries subsequently, including India, Peru, Kenya, and China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[419]</a></sup> The Mexican government successfully used a telenovela to promote family planning in the 1970s to curb the country's high birth rate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bilingual government radio stations broadcasting in Spanish and indigenous languages were a tool for indigenous education (1958–65) and since 1979 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_Indigenista" title="Instituto Nacional Indigenista">Instituto Nacional Indigenista</a> has established a national network of bilingual radio stations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[421]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Mexico" title="Sport in Mexico">Sport in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sobrevuelos_CDMX_IMG_5971_(25513748117).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3342" data-file-width="5013" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Sobrevuelos_CDMX_IMG_5971_%2825513748117%29.jpg/220px-Sobrevuelos_CDMX_IMG_5971_%2825513748117%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Sobrevuelos_CDMX_IMG_5971_%2825513748117%29.jpg/330px-Sobrevuelos_CDMX_IMG_5971_%2825513748117%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Sobrevuelos_CDMX_IMG_5971_%2825513748117%29.jpg/440px-Sobrevuelos_CDMX_IMG_5971_%2825513748117%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sobrevuelos_CDMX_IMG_5971_(25513748117).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Estadio_Azteca" title="Estadio Azteca">Azteca Stadium</a>, Mexico City.</div></div></div>
<p>Organized sport in Mexico largely dates from the late nineteenth century, with only <a href="/wiki/Bullfighting" title="Bullfighting">bullfighting</a> having a long history dating to the early colonial era. Once the political turmoil of the early republic was replaced by the stability of the <a href="/wiki/Porfiriato" title="Porfiriato">Porfiriato</a> did organized sport become public diversions, with structured and ordered play governed by rules and authorities.  Baseball was introduced from the United States and also via Cuba in the 1880s and organized teams were created. After the Mexican Revolution, the government sponsored sports to counter the international image of political turmoil and violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Baker_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-Baker-426">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p>The bid to host the <a href="/wiki/1968_Summer_Olympics" title="1968 Summer Olympics">1968 Summer Olympics</a> was to burnish Mexico's stature internationally, with is being the first Latin American country to host the games. The government spent abundantly on sporting facilities and other infrastructure to make the games a success, but those expenditures helped fuel public discontent with the government's lack of spending on social programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Baker_426-1"><a href="#cite_note-Baker-426">[422]</a></sup> Mexico City hosted the <a href="/wiki/1968_Summer_Olympics" title="1968 Summer Olympics">XIX Olympic Games</a> in 1968, making it the first Latin American city to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[423]</a></sup> The country has also hosted the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> twice, in <a href="/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1970 FIFA World Cup">1970</a> and <a href="/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1986 FIFA World Cup">1986</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[424]</a></sup> Mexico's most popular sport is association football. 
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:100_a%C3%B1os_del_natalicio_del_Santo_-i---i-_(36184746106).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="628" data-file-width="995" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/100_a%C3%B1os_del_natalicio_del_Santo_-i---i-_%2836184746106%29.jpg/220px-100_a%C3%B1os_del_natalicio_del_Santo_-i---i-_%2836184746106%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/100_a%C3%B1os_del_natalicio_del_Santo_-i---i-_%2836184746106%29.jpg/330px-100_a%C3%B1os_del_natalicio_del_Santo_-i---i-_%2836184746106%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/100_a%C3%B1os_del_natalicio_del_Santo_-i---i-_%2836184746106%29.jpg/440px-100_a%C3%B1os_del_natalicio_del_Santo_-i---i-_%2836184746106%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:100_a%C3%B1os_del_natalicio_del_Santo_-i---i-_(36184746106).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/El_Santo" title="El Santo">El Santo</a>, one of the most iconic Mexican <i><a href="/wiki/Lucha_libre" title="Lucha libre">luchadores</a></i></div></div></div>
<p>The Mexican professional baseball league is named the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liga_Mexicana_de_Beisbol" title="Liga Mexicana de Beisbol">Liga Mexicana de Beisbol</a>. While usually not as strong as the United States, the Caribbean countries and Japan, <a href="/wiki/Mexico_national_baseball_team" title="Mexico national baseball team">Mexico</a> has nonetheless achieved several international baseball titles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[426]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other sporting activities include <a href="/wiki/Bullfighting" title="Bullfighting">Bullfighting</a>, boxing, and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lucha_Libre" title="Lucha Libre">Lucha Libre</a></i> (freestyle professional wrestling). Bullfighting (Spanish: <i>corrida de toros</i>) came to Mexico 500 years ago with the arrival of the Spanish. Despite efforts by animal rights activists to outlaw it, bullfighting remains a popular sport in the country, and almost all large cities have bullrings. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plaza_M%C3%A9xico" title="Plaza México">Plaza México</a> in Mexico City, which seats 45,000 people, is the largest bullring in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[427]</a></sup> Freestyle professional wrestling is a major crowd draw with national promotions such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lucha_Libre_AAA_World_Wide" title="Lucha Libre AAA World Wide">AAA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Consejo_Mundial_de_Lucha_Libre" title="Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre">CMLL</a> and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sports_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-sports-432">[428]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico is an international power in <a href="/wiki/Professional_boxing" title="Professional boxing">professional boxing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sports_432-1"><a href="#cite_note-sports-432">[428]</a></sup> Thirteen <a href="/wiki/Mexico_at_the_Olympics" title="Mexico at the Olympics">Olympic boxing medals</a> have been won by Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[429]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-10">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i>México</i> or <i>Méjico</i>, both pronounced <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="es-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[ˈmexiko]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es-mx-M%C3%A9xico.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Es-mx-M%C3%A9xico.ogg" title="Es-mx-México.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>; <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a>: <i>Mēxihco</i></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Usually, in <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>, the name of the county is spelled as <i>México</i>, however, in the <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_Spanish" title="Peninsular Spanish">Peninsular Spanish</a>, spelling variant <i>Méjico</i>, is also used alongside the usual version. According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Diccionario_panhisp%C3%A1nico_de_dudas" title="Diccionario panhispánico de dudas">Diccionario panhispánico de dudas</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Academy" title="Royal Spanish Academy">Royal Spanish Academy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Academies_of_the_Spanish_Language" title="Association of Academies of the Spanish Language">Association of Academies of the Spanish Language</a>, the spelling version with J is correct, however, the spelling with X is recommended, as it is the one that is used in <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Spanish" title="Mexican Spanish">Mexican Spanish</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[10]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i>Estados Unidos Mexicanos</i>, <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="es-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[esˈtaðos uˈniðoz mexiˈkanos]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es-mx-Estados_Unidos_Mexicanos.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b9/Es-mx-Estados_Unidos_Mexicanos.ogg" title="Es-mx-Estados Unidos Mexicanos.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>, (<abbr title="literal translation">lit.</abbr>: United Mexican States), abbreviation: <i>EUM</i>; <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a>: <i>Mēxihcatl Tlacetilīlli Tlahtohcāyōtl</i></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-324"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-324">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Defined as persons who live in a household where an indigenous language is spoken by one of the adult family members or people who self-identified as indigenous ("Criteria del hogar: De esta manera, se establece, que los hogares indígenas son aquellos en donde el jefe y/o el cónyuge y/o padre o madre del jefe y/o suegro o suegra del jefe hablan una lengua indígena y también aquellos que declararon pertenecer a un grupo indígena."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[319]</a></sup>) AND persons who speak an indigenous language but who do not live in such a household ("Por lo antes mencionado, la Comisión Nacional Para el Desarrollo de los Pueblos Indígenas de México (CDI) considera población indígena (PI) a todas las personas que forman parte de un hogar indígena, donde el jefe(a) del hogar, su cónyuge y/o alguno de los ascendientes (madre o padre, madrastra o padrastro, abuelo(a), bisabuelo(a), tatarabuelo(a), suegro(a)) declaro ser hablante de lengua indígena. Además, también incluye a personas que declararon hablar alguna lengua indígena y que no forman parte de estos hogares."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[320]</a></sup>)</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-2020_Census-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-2020_Census_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2020_Census_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2020_Census_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2020_Census_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2020_Census_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <li id="cite_note-Bright2004-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Bright2004_38-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWilliam_Bright2004">William Bright (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=5XfxzCm1qa4C&amp;pg=PA281" rel="nofollow"><i>Native American Placenames of the United States</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-39">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20081101110558/http://ierd.prd.org.mx/coy128/hlb.htm" rel="nofollow">"El cambio de la denominación de "Estados Unidos Mexicanos" por la de "México" en la Constitución Federal"</a>. ierd.prd.org.mx. <li id="cite_note-131"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-131">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://elpais.com/diario/1990/09/01/cultura/652140001_850215.html" rel="nofollow">"Vargas Llosa: "México es la dictadura perfecta"<span class="cs1-kern-right"></span>"</a>. <i>El País</i>. 1 September 1990.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=El+Pa%C3%ADs&amp;rft.atitle=Vargas+Llosa%3A+%22M%C3%A9xico+es+la+dictadura+perfecta%22&amp;rft.date=1990-09-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Felpais.com%2Fdiario%2F1990%2F09%2F01%2Fcultura%2F652140001_850215.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-285"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-285">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFThomson,_Elizabeth_A.1995">Thomson, Elizabeth A. </li>

<li id="cite_note-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES-310"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES_310-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130823015618/http://www.nacionmulticultural.unam.mx/Portal/Izquierdo/BANCO/Mxmulticultural/Elmestizajeylasculturas-elmestizaje.html" rel="nofollow">"en el censo de 1930 el gobierno mexicano dejó de clasificar a la población del país en tres categorías raciales, blanco, mestizo e indígena, y adoptó una nueva clasificación étnica que distinguía a los hablantes de lenguas indígenas del resto de la población, es decir de los hablantes de español"</a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.nacionmulticultural.unam.mx/Portal/Izquierdo/BANCO/Mxmulticultural/Elmestizajeylasculturas-elmestizaje.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 23 August 2013.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=en+el+censo+de+1930+el+gobierno+mexicano+dej%C3%B3+de+clasificar+a+la+poblaci%C3%B3n+del+pa%C3%ADs+en+tres+categor%C3%ADas+raciales%2C+blanco%2C+mestizo+e+ind%C3%ADgena%2C+y+adopt%C3%B3+una+nueva+clasificaci%C3%B3n+%C3%A9tnica+que+distingu%C3%ADa+a+los+hablantes+de+lenguas+ind%C3%ADgenas+del+resto+de+la+poblaci%C3%B3n%2C+es+decir+de+los+hablantes+de+espa%C3%B1ol.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nacionmulticultural.unam.mx%2FPortal%2FIzquierdo%2FBANCO%2FMxmulticultural%2FElmestizajeylasculturas-elmestizaje.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-347"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-347">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFINALI_[Instituto_Nacional_de_Lenguas_Indígenas]2008"><a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Lenguas_Ind%C3%ADgenas" title="Instituto Nacional de Lenguas Indígenas">INALI [Instituto Nacional de Lenguas Indígenas]</a> (14 January 2008). <a class="external text" href="http://www.inali.gob.mx/pdf/CLIN_completo.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Catálogo de las lenguas indígenas nacionales: Variantes lingüísticas de México con sus autodenominaciones y referencias geoestadísticas"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF online facsimile)</span>. <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diario_Oficial_de_la_Federaci%C3%B3n" title="Diario Oficial de la Federación">Diario Oficial de la Federación</a></i> (in Spanish). <li id="cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-348"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_348-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_348-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_348-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://cuentame.inegi.org.mx/hipertexto/todas_lenguas.htm" rel="nofollow">"Indigenous Languages in Mexico: Speakers Aged Three or Older"</a>. <li id="cite_note-349"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-349">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130921054016/http://www.nacionmulticultural.unam.mx/Edespig/diagnostico_y_perspectivas/leyes_declaraciones/2%20LENGUA%20Y%20CULTURA/Ley%20general%20de%20derechos%20linguisticos.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Ley General de Derechos Lingüísticos de los Pueblos Indígenas"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (in Spanish). 2003.
